DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent government business taking precedence of all other business for this sitting.

As I think I pointed out yesterday in answer to a question from the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife), provided the numbers are here for it we will be following the normal course of action-or what has become the normal course of action-for these days of sittings when we are called back to deal with final matters dealt with by the Senate. On the first day, the Thursday, normal business is followed. On the second day we put forward the suggestion that we should follow the course that Government business takes precedence so that we can have the maximum degree of flexibility in dealing with material likely to be bounced between the two Houses. This has been the way it has been done in the past and the Government's suggestion is that it is the way it should be done today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FIFE
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Opposition Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) because it is clear that the Government will use its numbers to conclude the sitting of the House this afternoon, probably at 3 or 4 o'clock.

SPEECH.PARA: I will say once more for the benefit of the new members of this House and for people who might be listening in other parts of Australia that in 1990, if the Government follows the sitting pattern that has been published, this House will sit for fewer days than any other parliament in the past 50 years. It will be the second shortest sitting period since Federation. The only other occasion when Parliament sat for less time than is proposed on this occasion was, I think, in 1937.

Of course, this indicates the disregard the Government has for Parliament. If it could govern without this Parliament meeting this Government would govern without calling Parliament together, but it has to call Parliament together for Supply purposes and to get other legislation through. It is treating the Parliament with contempt and when a government treats Parliament with contempt it is, of course, treating the people with contempt.

I appeal to the Leader of the House to reassess the arrangements for what is termed the Budget session of Parliament with a view to adding at least two, and perhaps three, weeks to the period that the Government intends the House to sit. This will enable members on both sides of the House to properly scrutinise the legislation that comes before it.

My only other point at this moment is to say to the Leader of the House that he should reassess his arrangements in relation to these special sittings when it is necessary to bring the Parliament back for one or two days. Whenever Parliament meets the Government should take questions and allow time for matters of public importance-in other words, private members' business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Wool Marketing Act 1987 to provide a Commonwealth Government guarantee on all borrowings raised by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) before 1 July 1992 and interest on those borrowings. The Government agreed to provide the guarantee as one of several measures concerning the reserve price scheme for wool. The Government's guarantee provides a firm backing to the Australian Wool Corporation and reduces the risk of the financial sector reneging on loan agreements with the AWC. It will also assist the AWC to obtain access to credit on more favourable terms.

Mr Speaker, members of this House will be aware that yesterday I directed the AWC that the minimum market indicator reserve price for 1990-91 will be set at no more than 700c per kilogram clean. The direction which I issued is unprecedented. It is therefore appropriate if I address the general circumstances prevailing in the wool industry in this second reading speech.

The Government's decision was not taken lightly. It was taken after an exhaustive process of consultation with members of the Board of the AWC, with industry and with those involved in the processing and export of wool.

As I said in this place during the second reading debate on the wool tax Bills on 17 May, the wool industry is in a very serious situation. Demand has been very depressed over the past year and production has reached record levels. Prices have progressively moved down to the floor. Corporation purchases have been very high during the year and stocks have now reached record levels. The chilling fact is that forecasts made by the professional staff of the AWC point to a further massive build-up in stocks.

I have been closely watching the increase in AWC stocks since last year. However, because of the risks of altering market behaviour I have made no public comment on this issue until just recently. Because of commercial hazard I have been meeting with both the Chairman of the AWC and the leaders of the wool industry behind closed doors since late last year. In those meetings I emphasised my concerns about the prevailing market situation and the likely impact of this on the Corporation's activities.

Members of this place will be aware that late last year it was suggested that the Corporation would need an increase in the wool tax to a maximum rate of 15 per cent. More recently, it was obvious that 15 per cent would not be sufficient to fund the borrowing activities necessary to support a stockpile of unprecedented dimensions.

I admit that automatically providing an increase in the tax rate to 25 per cent caused me, and the Government, considerable concern. My concerns existed for a number of reasons: I was unconvinced that by tackling supply alone the industry would effectively manage the outlook into 1990-91; I was concerned that the international demand for wool would worsen in the 1991 year; I was apprehensive that this would result in additional borrowings by the Corporation and a level of stocks which could not be meaningful managed in just a few short years; I was dismayed at the prospect of a corporation with potential liquidity problems being required, in the not too distant future, to act drastically to clear an overhang of stocks; and I was concerned that growers were not fully informed about the risks associated with any of the options facing them.

On 3 May I met with representatives from the AWC and the Wool Council of Australia (WCA). I advised them of the Government's concern. I next met with the AWC Board on 18 May. The purpose of the meeting was to hear presentations from the members of the Board and the Corporation's professional staff on their commercial, economic and market assessments. My main concern was that all measures should be considered, that is, the reserve price, the wool tax, borrowing requirements and appropriate marketing strategies. I required a complete package which would protect the future viability of the industry and the long term interests of growers.

At Roma, I conveyed a similar message to that which I had put to the Corporation earlier: namely, to carefully and scrupulously examine the AWC's preferred option-which was a 25 per cent tax, a $4 billion borrowing limit and a floor of 870c per kilo-and compare the risks of this with a different set of measures. I could not bring myself to accept the AWC's preferred option because the risks to the industry and the Government appeared to be too great. The risk goes beyond allowing the industry to bankrupt itself. In bankrupting itself, it breaks the backbone of Australia's farm sector. With an 870c floor, AWC figures pointed to stocks of four to five million bales in a year's time. Two years out, the prospect was a full season's wool in stock. If demand fell further, say by 5 per cent-which is not totally unlikely given the situation in China, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and eastern Europe-the figures showed stocks at levels which would overhang the market into the late 1990s.

The costs of holding such stocks are enormous. Present stockholding costs are considered to be around $220 per bale per year. Most of this is taken in interest charges. The interest costs alone would amount to $720m per year on a stockpile of four million bales. If demand collapsed, then a stockpile of six million bales would be a real possibility. That is not a wool mountain; that is a wool mountain range. The interest costs of a stockpile of six million bales would be close to $1 billion per year.

Mr Speaker, these figures give us all cold comfort. These figures demonstrate that the returns to growers from holding massive stocks diminish at an extraordinary rate. These figures demonstrate that commercial returns to growers are not maximised with stocks at those levels. Given a 870c floor and given stocks of such dimension, the Corporation suggested that an upper borrowing limit of $4 billion would be required. This would occur even with a 25 per cent wool tax.

Such borrowings by a statutory authority would set a new precedent. They would act to increase pressure on domestic capital markets, increase our foreign debt and would result in interest rates remaining higher for a longer period than would otherwise be the case. Members of this House will know that AWC's borrowings are currently approved at an upper limit of $2.5 billion. Given this limit, it would be likely that the tax rate would rise beyond 25 per cent. If demand collapsed, then a tax rate of around 40 per cent would be a real possibility. The financial consequences for growers and the social costs to growers would be disastrous.

It was apparent after Roma that the AWC's and the industry's rock solid preference was for the 870c floor. This position was reached despite the presentations of AWC professionals. I, therefore, arranged to meet with the AWC and the Wool Council on 25 May to discuss again a viable package of measures which would not jeopardise the industry's viability. At this meeting the AWC put forward a new proposal based on a series of marketing initiatives. It considered that borrowings could be contained under the $2.5 billion limit, but a 25 per cent wool tax would be required over an extended period.

I asked for this proposal to be thoroughly evaluated by my officials and the expert and professional staff of the Corporation. Here I must say that I regard with contempt the statements by various people in the wool industry about the professional competence of people serving the Government and the Wool Corporation. The staff are doing their job and providing advice to the people that have to take the decisions, and nothing else.

I also gave notice to the Corporation that I was considering issuing a direction regarding the floor price. However, I made it clear that I wanted to see the evaluations of the AWC's proposal before taking final decision. I advised the Corporation that I would be discussing the matter with Cabinet before any action was taken. While I welcomed the effort put into the AWC's proposal, it was clear to me that it did not overcome the high risk of the 870c floor and 25 per cent tax option. The proposal was based on sustained increases in trade clearances of wool at unprecedented levels. These exceeded the levels achieved between 1984-85 and 1987-88. Simply, it meant a larger increase in clearances in the next six years than had occurred over the 40 years before 1986-87. Mr Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a graph which illustrates this point.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, this was a period of extremely rapid growth in demand, highlighted by the strong presence of China in the market. A marketing initiative does not, however, equate to firm orders. We could not afford to wait another year to see what prospects there were for increased sales. My main difficulty with the proposal was that it did not get to the heart of the industry's present problems. This simply relates to the basic economic forces of demand and supply. A price has been set at a level which has discouraged the consumption of wool in the face of competition with more price competitive substitute fibres. This has been particularly exacerbated by the foreign exchange problems of China and the USSR, two of our most important customers.

On the supply side, the price has encouraged an extraordinary increase in production. This increase has been boosted by an unusual run of good seasons. Shorn wool production has been at record levels in the past two years and these are likely to be exceeded again this year. The prospects of another record next year also look strong. At the current price levels, growers will simply not cut back wool production. The Australian Bureau of Statistics now tells us that we have five million more sheep than we previously thought. Our supply calculations have therefore been underestimated by five million sheep and the wool from five million sheep.

The industry, in general, accepts that the 870c per kilogram floor was set at too ambitious a level. The increase in the floor since 1986-87 has been a massive 71 per cent. If the floor had been set at a level consistent with the long-term trend in wool prices then there would be no issue before us today. However, had the floor been maintained at 870c per kilogram speculation about a reduction would not have diminished-not this year, not the next year. Such speculation would have increased if the market deteriorated further. Under these circumstances there is no logic in arguing that a correcting adjustment should not be made.

I had emphasised to the industry that an adjustment had to be made this year. At this time next year, with vastly expanded stocks, the types of options available to us today would simply not be available. Growers would have needed to pay whatever tax was necessary to meet the stockholding costs. Alternatively, the AWC would have had to go further into debt. We would have been gambling with high risk stakes; namely, the viability of one of our most important industries.

Another concern I had related to the reserve price scheme itself. In recent years the minimum reserve price changed from a means of managing large unexpected downturns in prices to a price support mechanism. This development guarantees that the correct price signals are not transmitted to producers. It also undercuts everything that the farm sector and the Government have been saying internationally on trade and agricultural reform. I also have concerns that the proposal for the AWC to hold a substantial level of stocks, as part of its marketing strategy, departs from the original intent of the scheme. The new proposal has connotations of an acquisition policy-a policy, I would add, rejected by the industry in the 1970s. Such major changes away from the original policy or legislative intent must be subject to open review and debate before being implemented.

In addition I reject any reliance on high tax rates for an extended period. With constrained AWC borrowing, growers could have faced the prospects of between 30 and 40 per cent of their wool receipts being taxed over a three- to five-year period. It was often suggested to me that this would discourage production and help bring the supply side under control. However, it is senseless not to give a market signal to growers on price, but only give them one on the tax rate. It is unacceptable, in my view, for a government to use taxing powers to force thousands of growers from the industry. When propositions such as this are raised I sometimes wonder whether it has been forgotten that Australia is a market economy.

Mr Speaker, for the reasons I have given, it was necessary for me to issue the direction to the Australian Wool Corporation to set and publish next season's reserve price at no more than 700c per kilogram clean. The Government believes that at this level the competitiveness of wool will be restored and stocks, borrowings and the wool tax rate will be able to be brought down to manageable levels more quickly than under the present floor price. The risks of the financial collapse of the AWC or the industry are substantially lower. Furthermore, the decision will restore the reserve price to its original purpose as a floor: to underwrite the market in order to protect growers against large sudden falls in wool prices.

In taking the decision to lower the floor, the Government will not contemplate, under any circumstances, further downward movement from this level. The decision of 700c as a floor is immutable. The wool trade can now act with confidence that the price will not be reduced further.

The Government has given tangible expression in offering to guarantee all borrowings of the Australian Wool Corporation for the next two years. Against this background, the Government has decided that a review of pricing policy in the wool industry should be conducted. The basic aim of such a review would be to analyse changes which have taken place since the current arrangements were introduced in 1974 and to recommend measures to make the arrangements more effective. I will be announcing details of the review at a later date. Let me make this perfectly clear: the Government's commitment to the 700c per kilogram floor is rock solid. Any recommendations will not be allowed to induce another dizzy round of speculation.

Of critical importance now is for the AWC and the industry leaders to manage the future, for the sake of the future and for the long-term benefit of growers. I have acted with the greatest reluctance. However, the Government, with the Corporation and with the Wool Council, intends to see the long-term future of growers and the wool industry secured.

Wool is of key importance to our rural economy and nationally. It contributes approximately 25 per cent of the value of agricultural production. Prior to the recent contraction in demand it was our major export commodity, contributing about $6 billion to our export income in 1988-89. This year its contribution is expected to be around $4 billion. In facing up to the difficulties that lie ahead of the wool industry, I recognise the critical role of wool promotion. The Government accepts its responsibility to assist the Corporation in its promotion and marketing efforts, particularly the new initiatives which have been proposed. Consequently, to boost the AWCs promotion funds, we will extend the Government's contribution to $75m over three years from 1991-92. This will continue from the Government's current commitment of $25m per annum which expires at the end of 1990-91.

I recognise that the combination of a high wool tax and a cut in the minimum reserve price will reduce the gross proceeds to growers from wool in the coming season. Of course, the alternative prescription would have done the same. Some small specialists who have few or no production alternatives will be hit hard.

However, growers' income needs to be considered in the context of what has happened over the past 10 years or so. And not just with the high incomes of the previous boom firmly in mind. With a 700c per kilogram floor and a 20 per cent tax the average cash surplus earned by wool growers in 1990-91 will still be above that earned in 1986-87. In fact, on average, it is projected to be as high as $15,000 above the cash surplus earned by growers in 1986-87. I would remind honourable members that most wool farms only receive about 50 per cent of their incomes from wool-the balance is derived from activities like beef for which the present market is strong.

In making my decision to reduce the floor I had to weigh up all the risks facing the industry and the short and long-term costs and benefits. Had I agreed to the 870c per kilogram-25 per cent tax proposal, then it is likely that this would have resulted in losses over the longer term of some $11,000 for every wool producing farm in this country. In addition, by 1993-94 the share of the Corporation's debt attributable to each wool producing farm, as a result of the Corporation supporting an 870c per kilogram floor price, would be around $60,000. Should the market worsen, and honourable members of this House can assess the risks associated with the trade into eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, then the prospects for growers under an 870c per kilogram floor would be very bleak indeed. That is why the Government flatly and categorically rejects the concept of compensation.

At this moment, it is not possible to obtain a firm idea of the number of growers who might be affected by the lower floor and higher tax. We recognise, however, that significant pressure may be placed on some individuals. Therefore, the Government is prepared to review the supply of funds under the rural adjustment scheme, including possible carry on assistance and structural adjustment. The intent of the Wool Marketing Act is that I should only use the power that the Parliament has given me to direct the Corporation in exceptional circumstances. In legal terms this means that ordinarily the functions and powers of the AWC are to be exercised without ministerial intervention.

I would like to take the opportunity here of reinforcing that intent. It was necessary for me to intervene in this case, because of exceptional circumstances, to ensure the future viability of the wool industry. I hope the need for such action will not arise again.

In over seven years as the responsible Minister, my main goal has been to get the wool industry and, indeed, other rural industries, to take responsibility for decision-making processes and to move these away from government. My record on reforming statutory marketing arrangements since 1983 speaks for itself. Despite the current events, I do not intend to back-track on what has been achieved in providing autonomy to the statutory marketing authorities, including the Australian Wool Corporation.

In the past few weeks the wool industry and its leaders, the Board of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Government have been through an extraordinarily difficult period. The decisions that have now been taken have not been easy for any of us. I am confident that the Board of the Australian Wool Corporation will be able to bring its best commercial expertise to the marketing of the massive stockpile of wool Australia has now.

Our first priority must be to send messages to our international markets that Australia is committed to the future of its wool industry and will stand firmly behind it. As part of this process, I propose to attend the fifty-ninth International Wool Conference of the International Wool Textile Organisation at Cavtat-Dubrovnik next week to convey this message to the world's processors of wool. I intend to convey this message, in the clearest possible terms, to the processors and manufacturers in Europe. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The events of the last few weeks have been devastating for Australia's greatest industry-the wool industry. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech has catalogued some of the events in that period. This legislation is a reflection of the turmoil that the industry is in. The manner of presentation of the Wool Marketing Amendment Bill 1990 is most unsatisfactory-and the Bill continues the Government's most unsatisfactory and messy handling of the whole wool issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We have one hour to consider a Bill which was received only late last night. It follows a 2 3/4 hour time limit on the wool tax Bills two weeks ago. So we have got 3 3/4 hours in the House of Representatives to debate those momentous events for our greatest industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful. I acknowledge that it is essential legislation-that is why we are accepting this procedure at this time-that goes some way to restoring confidence in the wool market following the Government's unprecedented intervention. That intervention initially destroyed the remaining two months of the wool selling season and Australian exports amounting to over $300m, when we need every export dollar, and resulted in an equal loss to growers of this country. By the intervention of the Minister of unilaterally lowering the floor price, the Australian Wool Corporation has lost credit worthiness. The industry has lost the credibility of the floor price system.

SPEECH.PARA: A statement made yesterday by the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr Beggs, acknowledged this most fragile and dangerous situation now facing the Corporation. It called on the Government to confirm that the 700c new minimum price could not alter. It called on the Government to guarantee borrowings for the Corporation because of its destroyed credit worthiness. That is the purpose of this Bill.

The action of the Minister yesterday and again in his second reading speech today indicates that the Government has listened to that urgent request of the industry. I commend the Minister and the Government for the action that they are now taking because speed is essential. The Corporation needs a credit rating to be able to maintain its borrowings arrangements. The guarantee that the Government is now putting into the wool marketing legislation is for a two-year period and, I understand, up to the $2 3/4 billion borrowing limit approval, which has already been granted by the Government to the Corporation.

Our support for this particular Bill is the first actual open support for the Government for any action it has taken in this very devastating period for the wool industry, which began several months ago. I say again today, as I did in a statement on behalf of the coalition yesterday, along with the Chairman of the Wool Corporation, Mr Beggs, and the President of the Wool Council of Australia, Mr Sawer: the decision has been made and, however reluctantly, sections of the industry ought to accept that decision. I can understand their extreme reluctance, but there is no point doing anything other than accepting that decision, because everybody must be seen to be united to ensure that this great industry of ours is restored to its former viability-not just for the sake of the woolgrowers of Australia but for the sake of all Australians. On a net basis, wool still remains our major export industry, and I believe that the industry will return to that position soon on a gross basis.

The statement made on behalf of the coalition confirmed again our belief that it is the industry's right to set the floor. All we were doing was confirming our support for the Minister's own 1987 legislation which enshrined that right and on which the Minister has reneged. The important point is that everyone accepts that the decision has been made and we should get on with it. It is important for wool to be able to move immediately; for sales to continue; to build up confidence, to get those export dollars again; and to keep the Wool Corporation's borrowings at a reasonable level.

I commend the quick action of the Wool Corporation, which yesterday released an action plan for a continuous buying and reselling operation which will start with the reopening of the wool sales again next week-Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in Melbourne and Wednesday and Thursday in Sydney. Over 100,000 bales of wool are to be sold, and about half a million bales of wool are still to be sold before the end of the wool selling season. Only after 1 July can the floor price formally and officially be changed to the new lower level.

It is my belief that there will be a considerable and very good clearance of wool, but that in no way means that the wool will be cleared because it is being sold at 700c, versus 870c, or at any other level. It will be cleared because buyers have deliberately stayed away from the market for some time and the textile pipeline is about one million bales shorter than it ever has been before, so there is a tremendous pent-up demand out there for wool, and I hope and I believe that, now that everything is finally settled, the clearances will dramatically increase.

The Minister, in his speech, refers also to promotion. The Wool Corporation, in its final submission to the Minister and the Government, gave details of a new marketing strategy to increase demand in what is sometimes called the middle market, to get better sales for the somewhat coarser types of wool, but still relatively fine wool, in the lighter fabrics that are now favoured by people. This will cost $60m to $70m, and with any marketing strategy it will take time.

The Minister, by his statement this morning, has removed uncertainty in relation to what happens to the Government's contribution to wool promotion when the present three year Government contribution of $25m per year finishes at the end of the next financial year. The Minister has indicated that it will continue for another three years at the same level.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a reduction.

—I take the point that it is, in real terms, a reduction; it is a dramatic reduction from the agreement reached between the Government and the industry some years ago. It is actually well under half, in real terms, of what the Government was providing for promotion. Nevertheless, I believe it is important that that announcement is made at this time and that it is supported.

SPEECH.PARA: In case people think that, somehow, the industry is getting something from government better than anybody else, I remind them that there is no other industry in this country where the individual members of that industry contribute so much to promotion. About $190m of their own money, in good years and bad years, is provided to make sure and to maintain that market for wool at a quality price as a quality fabric.

That also raises the question that the grower contribution to promotion may have to rise from the present 3 3/4 per cent level. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) has calculated that of the 20 per cent maximum total wool levy or tax that can now be applied to growers, a maximum of 16 per cent should meet the greatest degree of market support needed by the Wool Corporation. I think that carries with it two omens or two further points: one is that there is a safety margin there for the wool industry if more is needed; and, secondly, there is an ability to increase the promotion levy. But one has to make the cautionary comment that woolgrowers' income will be dramatically reduced and therefore there should be no additional impost on growers without the complete consideration of `is it needed' and what that means to the industry.

The Minister has also referred to rural adjustment, or adjustment that will be needed in the industry. When we look at a 16 per cent levy, which will, I acknowledge, only be there for one year, according to ABARE and its calculations, the woolgrowers are looking at an average reduction of at least 35 per cent and potentially far higher in their income because of this decision. That is a dramatic reduction. The Minister has stated that it is still above the 1986-87 cash income for growers, but of course that has not been adjusted for inflation, and it comes also at a time when we have a Treasurer who continually says that the work force of Australia has suffered no loss whatsoever in real income, yet the woolgrowers of this country are being asked to take at least a 35 to 40 per cent reduction in real income, and they are the components of the most internationally efficient industry in this country.

The Minister does recognise that there will be growers at risk, big numbers of them, and he has listened to the calls of many people, including me, that the rural adjustment scheme should be used within its limits. One acknowledges the limits; it means only a small percentage will be helped. But at least that has been included in his statement and he makes the point that more funds will be needed.

I also suggest to the Minister that, as well as keeping an eye on the rural adjustment scheme, where it is necessary to ensure that growers are assisted as much as they can be within the limits of the scheme, a review of the income equalisation deposits (IED) scheme be made. The reality will be that with the dramatic reduction in woolgrowers' incomes the level at which it is worthwhile for growers to participate in IEDs will be reached by very few people. Woolgrowers, as well as having to face the reduction in income, still face the vagaries of our climatic situation. Of course, that is one of the purposes of the IED scheme. I ask the Minister to look again at changing the criteria and the tax levels, et cetera, so that the IED scheme is still relevant.

This dramatic reduction in growers' income was one of the main points of grower anger directed at the Government over this whole issue. Secondly, the growers' anger has been directed at the disastrous public intervention by the Government, which has ruined the last two months of the wool sales. Thirdly, the growers have been angered at the refusal by the Government to accept the industry proposals, the industry calculations, particularly when the industry itself well remembers that in 1970, 1975 and 1985 the industry backed its judgment against the judgment of all the economists and was proved to be right; and the industry believes that that is still the case.

The final part of the growers' anger has been at the double standard of the Government saying to the industry that it has certain economic policies which means that the industry has to meet the `market'; that foreign borrowing may be good for everybody else but not for the industry; that the `market' is there for the industry but not for other sectors of the economy; and that nothing is being done to address the added costs to all exporters, including growers, as a result of the Government's economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is shameful. I want to refer to the last of those points but, because of the restrictions of time in this debate, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the statements of the Australian Wool Corporation, the Wool Council and the 12 questions proposed by the New South Wales Farm Association. This indicates-I believe correctly-the attitude of the wool industry on this important issue.
—Is there any objection to that incorporation?
—What is the form of the material?
—It will be a question of whether it fits within the guidelines of Hansard as well.
—I will now refer very briefly to the last area of anger, and it is encapsulated in the following amendment that I move on behalf of the Opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its:

(1) high interest rate and high inflation policies which have appreciated our exchange rates and reduced our competitiveness against the textile fibre industries in other countries where rates are less; and

I believe that that very clearly indicates the double standard of the Government in relation to economic management. With the further reduction in income for growers and exporters, it just exacerbates an already unfair and difficult situation.

In conclusion, I indicate the support of the coalition for the amendment to the Wool Marketing Act. Once again, I reiterate and support the comments by Mr Beggs and Mr Sawer, the leaders of the two sections of the wool industry, that at this difficult time we must all ensure that we get together and get on with restoring this great industry once again to profitability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I formally second the amendment, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment to the Wool Marketing Act 1987 totally guarantees the floor price of 700c. That is what this Act is all about-to give some stability and guarantee to the wool industry. The one pleasing thing that has been said by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd)-and I fully endorse what he said-is that we all need to work together to ensure that we can guarantee that this industry gets back to where it should be; that is, right at the top of the table.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry has come through some tough times. I guess basically the problems that we face have been a consequence of the fact that the floor price was far too high and we had to acknowledge market forces. That is the reality of the commercial world. I believe that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has shown leadership and courage in taking the tough decisions. One can never please everybody when there are tough decisions to make.

It has been interesting to note that there have been arguments on both sides of the fence. One argument was to maintain a high floor price of 870c and the other argument was to bring it down. During the debate various propositions have been put, but at the end of the day what is needed is some tough leadership and some courage; and I believe that that has been shown by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. When there is so much wool stored in stockpiles and when competitors to wool, the synthetics, are able to get access to the market, it is not just a case of spending more money on promotion which will sell our wool. It is the price that matters.

We have heard arguments many times from the other side about meeting the market forces-a bit of free enterprise. In this instance I think it is inevitable that we had to meet the market. Consequently, I believe that the decision to bring the floor price to 700c has been commonsense. In fact, I was looking at the editorial in the Australian today, a paper that I have much pleasure in reading. It embraces free market forces all the time. It tells us about the new wave that is coming from Victoria to free up the labour market and free up everything else. It was the greatest apologist editorial that I have ever seen. It was about trying to maintain the floor price at 870c. That is an incredible statement. It just makes one wonder how much sincerity really exists when those who charge the barricades in one instance, when it really comes the crunch turn out to be just so many closet agrarian socialists.

The Minister has shown a lot of courage and guts. That is what is needed in primary industries because there are always tough decisions that have to be made out in the rural sector. I believe that farmers recognise that. As the honourable member for Murray said, as a consequence, farmers will face tough times, with a drop in income of about 30 per cent. But had we maintained that floor price, the borrowings and the interest would have wiped out the value of the stockpiles in about four years. That would have been economic madness. Consequently, I think people really needed to know the way it is. For too long-and I say this in all sincerity-politicians on all sides of the House have often tried to say it the way people like to hear it. It is about time that we said it the way it is. In this instance the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has said it the way it is; that is, that the floor price has to come down and we have to face economic reality. It is about time that everyone got together, faced up to that, and worked to sell and promote our wool.

I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Murray and the Opposition are going to support us in that regard. It is not the Wool Corporation that is leading the way here; it is the Minister who is leading the way. Everyone else is following the Minister. It is not the Wool Corporation that is leading the way; the Minister has dragged it screaming into this position. I am pleased to see that it is now going to follow him and his determination to see a revitalised wool industry because it is the Minister's ideal, not the Wool Corporation's, that is going to lead us into the future.

While we are talking about borrowings, I believe that as a consequence of the dropping of the price we are going to save $1 billion. I would like to see consideration given to spending a large amount of money, if the Wool Corporation wants to gamble, in developing a fully integrated wool and textile industry here in Australia. Some consideration should be given to value adding the whole industry in this country and producing the final product here. I think it is madness to sell a raw product overseas and to let the buyers over there turn it into a finished garment. We should look at having a high technology industry right here in Australia. That should be considered along with wool promotion. I believe that we now have to get together and work to ensure that the wool industry does take its rightful place again as the leading exporter in primary industries.

With regard to compensation, the Minister has spelt that out very clearly. If we had not dropped the floor price the industry would have lost $1 billion. So the argument for compensation is silly. I believe that the Wool Corporation will support the Government. I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Murray and the Opposition are supporting it. All we need to do now is get on with the job and work together to ensure that this industry does get back to where it belongs. The vagaries of the marketplace are something that we always have to endure. At present sugar is on a high; it was down three years ago. Wool will come back. Wool has been good in the past. Only two years ago it was over 1,200c. We should take cognisance of that.

In regard to the labour market and labour market reform that was commented on, I would like to say that no group in society has demonstrated such sacrifice and commitment to this economy as has the labour market, the workers of this country-the six million people who work and sell only one commodity, their labour. They have seen a reduction in real terms of more than 10 per cent. They are prepared to do that to see a better economy. It makes me wonder when people say that the labour market has to carry the can. It is carrying the can. It is prepared to do that. It has a commitment to this country.

The other interesting thing in regard to this wool debate is that throughout the debate, while we have heard the squattocracy put forward its views of closet agrarian socialism and the Opposition, particularly the National Party, has agonised over this issue-I am pleased to see that the Liberal Party has supported us all the way down the line-no-one asked the shearers what their views are. They too have an income and an interest in this industry. No-one has asked them. There are thousands of shearers involved in the wool industry. No-one on the other side has ever bothered to ask what they think about the floor price going down. That is the sad thing. It is interesting to note that next year we are going to celebrate 100 years since Barcaldine, under that tree, where the shearers did have an impact, importance and input into this country-that is, in the formation of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Workers Union. At the end of the day they and the wool industry will be there.

I am very pleased to support this amendment. We have had to face challenge in this industry. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has had the courage to make some tough decisions. He has to wear a few bullets. At the end of the day history will judge that he has had the guts to do that. At the same time as he has done that the Opposition has been divided. The Opposition has sat on a barbed wire fence, as Don Chipp once said, and lost the ball game. It is interesting to see that at a time when there are tough decisions to be taken the new revitalised National Party has gone to water on this issue. It is the Minister who is the prime minister of the bush. It is good to see that this amendment has been made and that the floor price has come down to 700c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Wool Marketing Amendment Bill that we are discussing is to provide a government guarantee for up to $2 3/4 billion of loans which may be required by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) under the new floor price arrangements of 700c-arrangements imposed upon the industry by the Government in recent days. I was glad to hear that in his closing remarks the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) supported our amendment.
—I didn't. I supported the amendment in the Bill.

—The honourable member did not. He said that he supported the amendment and I was pleased to hear it. I am sorry to hear the honourable member for Hinkler refer to those old hackneyed words such as `squattocracy' and make the mistake of thinking that in the short term shearers' wages would be affected by the arrangements and the unfortunate happenings in the wool industry today. Of course, shearers' wages in the short term will not be affected.

SPEECH.PARA: Until several years ago the Government provided a guarantee against borrowings by the Wool Corporation. At that time the industry, and presumably the Government, thought that it was sophisticated enough to have more autonomy and less government back-up. As such it was prepared to relinquish that government guarantee. It obviously thought that it was able to handle itself with less government support. I must say that I was one of those who was in favour of added independence for the wool industry and would therefore normally not be in favour of running back to the Government for support. However, in these circumstances I see no alternative but to embrace this proposition of a guarantee immediately in the interests of price stability and user confidence and in the national interest. I understand that it is not an open-ended guarantee, that it is for $2.5 billion and that it is to last for two years.

I also understand that the office of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is not yet sure whether this AWC borrowing will be caught by the Commonwealth borrowing levy. I understand that that matter is being examined by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) at this time. I also note that the proposition is that the promotion contribution of the Government will go back to the recent arrangements of $25m a year and will go on from the years 1991-92 for three years, but will not go back to the old arrangements which I negotiated, if I remember rightly, with the Minister when I had been President of the Wool Council of Australia for some time and he was a very new Minister. We negotiated a contribution based on a percentage of the gross proceeds of the wool clip.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much would that be now?

—My guess is that about $50m to $60m would be the proceeds. This is a very real cut in government promotion and, as we know, it has been brought back only by the unfortunate circumstances that the industry finds itself in.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the reserve price itself, this matter has been difficult for the Opposition. Firstly, there are only three players that can get into the game under the new arrangements that were brought in several years ago. Those three players are the Australian Wool Corporation, the Wool Council of Australia and the Government. They are the players and the rest of us can only make noises. Secondly, over the last two or three weeks the industry has repeatedly told us that it is its decision and it is its negotiation to have with the Government. Many of us in the Opposition were asked to keep out of the debate at least until the last few days. I have to say that in the main that wish has been observed.

We also had some difficulty in following the positions of the industry as it moved fleetingly only several months ago from a 15 per cent tax through to a 20 per cent tax to a 25 per cent tax and, as late as last Friday, a 25 per cent tax for five years, and, as I understand it, subsequently to a modified position. Not only have we had some difficulty in following those positions, but many of us, I have to confess, were unconvinced by the figures as we extracted them.

Questions were raised in our minds, some of which have already been raised this morning. Firstly, would the Corporation survive at 870c if there was still to be a stockpile, for example, of between 4.5 and 5.5 million bales at the end of June 1995? Many of the simulations that the Corporation has done show just those sorts of figures. This was the prognosis of the Corporation, and it seemed to suggest to us that there would be wool still in the stockpile in the year 2000 that is currently being held.

Secondly, what were the borrowing arrangements for a debt of $4 billion and above? Many of us on this side of the House were unconvinced that the Wool Corporation could survive holding such stocks over such a long time and that it would give rise to debts of this order.

It is now generally accepted that the setting of a reserve price two years ago at 870c was a mistake. Anyone who does not think so belongs to the group who wishes to push the price. History shows unequivocally that such systems invariably fail.

I believe that the mere doubling of the floor price in two years has been a tragic mistake. It has been called a floor price. It was called a floor price back in the early days-in the early 1970s-for very good reasons. Those reasons were that it initially made provision for wool to be brought in at a price below which the growers simply refused to sell to the world. Firstly, that price was one which we believed could be sustained over time. It was not a price which was designed to set the market for wool throughout a year or over the years. It was a base price which we could afford to provide the finance for and one which, as I said, we could sustain.

Secondly, it was a price which was to give some predictability to the buyer. That varies from country to country because buyers currencies vary from day to day. In fact, the only currency in which the price is constant is Australian dollars.

As I mentioned earlier in this debate, in the early 1970s we were looking at trying to maintain a sheep flock of just over 130 million when the flock was going down. Therefore, as time went on, the reserve price started to bear some relation to the size of that flock and to the maintenance of that flock. The 130 million in the early 1980s was low in historical terms. We wanted to make sure that the price was not set so low that we actually could not provide our customers with enough wool.

As I have said, the price was discussed many times. It was not supposed to be a price that was directly related to the cost of production, but in an indirect sense it became just that. It most certainly was not supposed to be a price which became the floor price which became the market price.

There are some lessons to be learned from this. It is often said that universities and such places are full of knowledge. The freshman brings some in, the senior takes little out, and therefore knowledge accumulates. I hope that the wool industry in this circumstance is accumulating some knowledge, and I most certainly hope that the Government is. I would now like to turn to the subject of the Government's performance in this matter.

It is now a matter of record that the Government did not set up a mechanism several years ago by which the floor could be lowered without interim disruption to the marketplace. We have had that interim disruption to the marketplace. It follows that the Government did not anticipate that a fall was possible. Of course, we know that such a fall in the floor price was not only undesirable; it turned out to be quite tragic. The floor price should never fall. It should be set at a level which is sustainable.

The Minister I note has been quite voluble on the subject of sustainable agriculture of late, and I agree with him. Nevertheless, the Minister did set up an arrangement whereby parts of the industry were able, in various states of excitement about high prices at the time, to push the price. For that he must take his part of the blame, just as a designer of any system which seriously malfunctions must take the blame.

I have not noticed anyone taking much responsibility in this debate until now. It is time one or two people admitted to some of it. I for one take some responsibility for not being able to persuade in the past those people who I have just mentioned who have always wanted to make the floor price the market price. I am sad that I have been unable to dissuade them from the idiocy of their ways. I do not have any philosophical basis for saying that, but simply the historical fact that every industry which has tried to push its price has finally finished under the water. The old principles of the very successful floor price scheme-and it was a very successful floor price scheme and will be again-still hold. If those principles were observed again, then quite simply, the scheme would be a success again.

There have been a few furphies put about over the last few weeks. One of them is that the dropping of the price to 700c will put more people out of business than having, for instance, a tax of 25 per cent for three or five years. The Wool Corporation's figures do not show that. The Wool Corporation's figures show that at around about the middle of this decade, on either of these two precepts, we will have dropped off around a quarter of our wool clip. I happen to think that that will not quite happen.

The second furphy that is around is that 700c as a reserve in itself will break a lot of people. I do not believe that that is true. What may be true is that if that price is combined with a very high tax for a long period many more people may go under. In itself, 700c, 680c, or 740c or any other such figure is not a figure that is going to break a lot of woolgrowers. I base that remark on the fact that everybody now recognises that 870c is a reserve price that is too profitable, and we thus have too many sheep in Australia.

There is a third idea about that we will need to hold a substantial stockpile, even as high as two or three million bales, people are saying, to stabilise the marketplace. I hope that somebody has worked out the cost of such a holding because I believe it is quite monstrous. It is somewhere in the order of $500m to $700m a year, depending on the interest rate. That new thought should be very seriously examined before anybody embarks on that road.

Our amendment is to condemn the Government. I have brushed upon that matter. There is no doubt that if interest rates were at reasonable levels, then the interest rate component of $180 of storage per year for a bale of wool would not be so high. If the exchange rate had not been held up by the interest rate parachute, then again we would sell more wool because it would be cheaper to people in other parts of the world in other currencies who buy our wool. If the rate of progress on the waterfront had been anything but slow and abysmal-had it been at any pace better than that-lots of things in that area would have improved. We can go all through those areas and criticise the Government for the lack of pace of its change.

To come back to one area that was mentioned by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), had we not had the removal of income equalisation deposits some seven or nine years ago, for reasons that I regard as spurious, many of those growers who were in a good position in the last two years would not have been put in the position where their ability to save had been affected detrimentally. The whole purpose of the IED scheme was to put in place to some extent an averaging ability, but more than that-to enable people to put money into the bank at low interest rates, albeit held by the Government, and to be able to pull it out again in bad times. Unfortunately this Government, early in its tenure, saw fit to remove the IED scheme and, when it put it back, it was far too late and not in a form that has been taken up with enthusiasm.

All in all, this has been a sad event. I hope that some lessons have been learned not only by the industry but by the Government and by us all. As the Chairman of the Wool Corporation has said, it is time that we all got back to work and got on with it. It is time that we put out of our minds our particular ideas as to what has been right and wrong in the last few days, that we support the Corporation, that we support the industry and that we make sure-as this Bill will help to do-that those people who buy our wool and who therefore are our greatest sellers of this commodity at the other end of the world are reassured by these arrangements and we get on with the job.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF AERONAUTICAL RESEARCH LABORATORY SITE, FISHERMENS BEND, VICTORIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of Aeronautical Research Laboratory site, Fishermens Bend, Vic.

The Aeronautical Research Laboratories, or ARL, are part of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation of the Department of Defence. Their terms of reference are to develop, maintain and exploit scientific and technological skills and facilities in areas generally central to military air vehicles and relevant aspects of weapons for the benefit of the Australian Defence Force. Existing laboratory and office accommodation at ARL is overcrowded and unsuitable for effective research, development and investigation in a number of areas of technology. Until 30 June 1988, ARL operated from a 9.55 hectare site at Fishermens Bend, Port Melbourne, leased from the Victorian State Government for a period of 50 years. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) occupied an adjacent 2.75 hectare site also leased from the Victorian State Government under the same arrangement.

On expiry of the leases on 30 June 1988, the entire 12.3 hectare site was purchased by the Commonwealth from the State Government. The Department of Defence is planning to purchase useable ex-CSIRO buildings on the site this financial year with the aim of refurbishing them, and some existing ARL buildings, to accommodate the expansion of ARL. The redevelopment proposal evolved from a need to rationalise the operation and management of the research facility and will provide badly needed laboratory and office space enabling certain staff to be collocated.

Health and safety surveys and site investigations commissioned by Defence and arranged by Australian Construction Services identified areas of hazardous chemical and radiation contamination on the ex-CSIRO site. Specifically, asbestos and dangerous wastes have been found in, or near, buildings previously used by the CSIRO and steps are being taken to manage the disposal of both. In addition, low levels of radiation detected within, or near, 10 buildings have now been cleared.

The Department of Defence will be monitoring and surveying the removal of the contaminants from the site and a proviso written into the environmental certificate of compliance that construction will not proceed until the site is clear of contaminants will be strictly observed.

The project will consist largely of refurbishment and demolition works and will provide functional laboratory facilities to support the advanced technologies embodied in recent aircraft acquisitions such as the FA18 fighter, Black Hawk and Seahawk helicopters. The works will also rectify temporary arrangements for laboratories, workshops and offices that have evolved over the past 40 years and rationalise facilities and accommodation. Also included is the provision of roads and car parking, additional electrical power to refurbished buildings, extension of the existing ARL security system to ex-CSIRO buildings and extension of the communication ducting network.

The limit of cost estimate for the proposed work, at December 1988 prices, is $16.2m and the work will be undertaken in two phases to accommodate funding arrangements of ARL. Commencement of phase A is planned for 1990-91. The proposed work is expected to provide employment on site for some 50 people and opportunities for the local building industry. I table selected plans of the proposed redevelopment of the ARL site and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this debate I indicate that the Opposition obviously supports this move and sees that it is important that the Aeronautical Research laboratory does, in fact, move to this or a similar site. We also believe that it is important that it stays in Melbourne because clearly the main customers of the research laboratory are in Melbourne, namely, the Royal Australian Air Force and, to a lesser extent, other services. Therefore, I think it is important from a practical point of view and from an economical point of view to maintain that proximity. It is also very important to see that this site is cleared of its contaminants and radioactive waste which, apparently, were discovered when the proposal to move to this site was first being undertaken. I look forward to the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works taking the opportunity to expedite this decision as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this particular matter and make a comment of a personal nature about the reference of the redevelopment of the Aeronautical Research Laboratory site at Fishermens Bend, Victoria, to the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. This reference comes back to the House having been brought to the House previously during the last parliamentary session.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that the role of the Public Works Committee, a joint statutory committee of this Parliament, is to look at references and consider, where appropriate if the Committee deems it necessary, other alternatives for the expenditure of capital funds. That is the role of the Committee and the Parliament has empowered it to make that determination.

With regard to this particular proposal, there is another proposal from Tasmania, which was lodged with the Committee under its previous terms of reference and which has now been re-endorsed, for the consideration of a site in Tasmania. The Committee has already voted to conduct an inspection in Tasmania of the proposal that has been put forward. I just want to draw to the attention of honourable members that that is taking place, and that it is a proper function of the Committee, albeit that it might be to the displeasure of those within the Defence, Science and Technology Organisation who have expressed that view publicly, in advance, I might say, of consideration by the Committee. I believe it to be an incorrect statement on their part, and of a public nature.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF PERTH OFFICE AND WAREHOUSE COMPLEX FOR CIVIL AVIATION AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move;

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of Perth office and warehouse complex for the Civil Aviation Authority.

In 1988 the Civil Aviation Authority purchased land at Perth Airport with the view of relocating to the airport all office-based staff presently located in leased office space in the central business district. Investigation into the economic feasibility of this proposition confirmed that the construction of a new office complex would reduce the overall cost of the CAA's Western Australian accommodation expenses. The financial analysis also involved the disposal of the existing warehouse site at Mount Claremont, Western Australia.

The scope of the project comprises: 5,438 square metres of office space, on two levels inclusive of reception area and staff amenities; 1,120 square metres of warehouse space; provision for 177 staff, fleet and visitor parking bays; systems furniture installation, consistent with modern working conditions: landscaping of site, including the retention of existing trees where practicable and mechanical, electrical, PABX and security services, consistent with the latest cost-effective technology.

The CAA's estimate of costs based on an October 1991 completion date totals $13.9m. This includes full allowance for cost escalation, furniture and fittings, PABX, consultant fees and contingencies. The work is being designed by private consultants to comply with the requirements of relevant authorities, and is consistent with the Commonwealth's accommodation guidelines. Extensive consultation has occurred with relevant staff associations on all aspects of the facilities to be provided.

In order to ensure earliest termination of existing leases totalling $100,000 per month, the CAA seeks to award a contract for the construction works by late August 1990 and to achieve completion during October 1991. I table preliminary building layout drawings of the proposal and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference to the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works of the construction of a Perth office and warehouse complex for the Civil Aviation Authority makes a lot of sense. I take this opportunity, firstly, of thanking the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) for giving me copies of material on this issue, and the last two, before today's parliamentary sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess one would again ask the question why it has taken us so long to do something that is plainly very sensible. Obviously the Civil Aviation Authority will be able to function better if its personnel are situated at the airport rather than in the central business district of Perth. Therefore, I hope that the Public Works Committee will be able to consider this as soon as practicable, and the sooner it happens the better.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEDICATED COMPUTER CENTRE FOR AUSTRALIAN TAXATION OFFICE, BRUCE, AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Dedicated computer centre for the Australian Taxation Office, Bruce, Australian Capital Territory.

This proposal is for the construction of a dedicated computer centre for the Australian Taxation Office on Commonwealth land at Bruce in the Australian Capital Territory. Honourable members may recall that approval to refer this proposal was given at the sitting of this House on 21 December 1989. Although a hearing by the former Public Works Committee had been scheduled for 26 February 1990, this did not eventuate because of the election. The need for referral is a consequence of the original motion having lapsed.

The Australian Taxation Office is undergoing a complete modernisation of its business operation and has an urgent requirement to accommodate its new computer equipment in a secure and stable environment. The existing taxation computer facility in the Treasury building has outlived its functional usefulness and cannot provide for expansion needs over the next decade.

The proposed building of 6,300 square metres will consist of two levels. The computer mainframe and operations will be on the upper floor level while plant, dispatch, loading dock, storage, staff amenities and office accommodation will be on the ground floor level.

The Bruce site, adjacent to the Fern Hill Technology Park development, was found to be the most appropriate and effective location for meeting Australian Taxation Office needs, now and in the future. The limit of cost estimate for the proposal is $21.85m at December 1989 prices. I table drawings of the proposed works and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference to the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for the construction of a dedicated computer centre for the Australian Taxation Office in Bruce in the Australian Capital Territory is obviously supported. As has been pointed out, it was brought before the last Parliament in December of last year. Unfortunately, because the Government chose to call an election, this reference was delayed.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess one could make one comment here-that it is amazing how long it has taken for this Government to realise the need to do something like this. DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 31 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill would amend the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 to allow the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees, or Comcare as it is known, to take account of the amount that former employees are able to earn in calculating their rate of weekly benefits. The Bill would also ensure that the Act applies to the non-police staff members of the Australian Federal Police appointed since 1 January 1990, when certain new employment arrangements for these staff took effect.

Comcare was established to administer legislation on safety, rehabilitation and compensation for Commonwealth employees which came into effect on 1 December 1988. The objectives of the new scheme are to reduce the incidence and costs of work related injury in Commonwealth employment; to return injured employees to work as soon as possible; to provide fairer income related benefits for injured workers; to make employers more accountable for the costs of injury, illness and unsafe workplaces; and to improve the efficiency of decision making about compensation entitlements. Comcare has made significant progress towards achieving these objectives with an approach based on the integration of prevention, rehabilitation and compensation.

The new benefits package, which came into effect on 1 December 1988, reduces the financial hardship formerly experienced by injured workers, especially those with long term work disabilities. Early intervention by rehabilitation experts ensures that programs are implemented and employees return to work in far greater numbers and sooner than before. The premium system provides incentives to encourage the prevention of workplace injuries and disease through improved occupational health and safety practices and the rehabilitation of injured or sick workers.

As a result of the new legislation Comcare has been able to achieve a saving of $12m, or 14 per cent, of the projected cost made between December 1988 and June 1989. This corresponds to a full year saving of around $20m. These savings have been made possible, notwithstanding the generally higher level of benefits payable to injured workers, because of the emphasis on reducing the incidence of injury and rehabilitating those employees unfortunate enough to be injured at work. Comcare's premiums are comprehensive and competitive. There are no excess payments or hidden costs. Comcare's average premium in 1989-90 was 2.6 per cent of salary, which compares favourably with 3 per cent charged in reformed State schemes.

The new scheme has produced significant reductions in the duration of claims. The average length of claims in general has been reduced and, more importantly, there are fewer new claims becoming long term claims. These trends are occurring sooner than expected and are generating substantial savings to the Commonwealth and its authorities which are now directly responsible for the costs associated with work related injuries. As a result, the average premium rate for the 1990-91 financial year is expected to fall from 2.6c per wage and salary dollar to 2c. The immediate reduction in the duration of claims under the new scheme and the expected reduction in premium rates demonstrate the real value of the new approach which is achieving this Government's goals of reducing both the human and financial costs of work related injuries.

The amendments which would be made to the Act by this Bill have significant implications. The Bill would amend sections 131 and 132 of the Act, which relate to the amount of compensation payable to former employees. Former employees are defined in the Act to mean persons who were receiving compensation under the repealed Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and who had ceased to be employees of the Commonwealth before the commencement of the Act on 1 December 1988. Special transitional provisions were included in the Act to protect former employees from the full operation of certain provisions of the Act, such as the age 65 cut-off of benefits and the dollar for dollar reduction in compensation benefits payable to persons entitled to weekly superannuation benefits.

Sections 131 and 132 of the Act set out methods of calculating the amount of weekly compensation payable to former employees. Section 131 deals with those former employees who are in receipt of superannuation benefits, while section 132 applies to those with no superannuation entitlements. As currently drafted, neither section allows Comcare to have any regard to the amount that former employees are able to earn in suitable employment. `Able to earn' tests of this nature are common to all workers compensation Acts in Australia. However, a provision which would have enabled Comcare to have regard to the amount that former employees are capable of earning was omitted from the legislation.

The amendments provide that the amount of compensation payable to a former employee who has a residual capacity for work will be either the amount that he or she is currently receiving, less the amount that he or she is able to earn in suitable employment; or the amount payable under the Act to a current employee of the Commonwealth with similar earning capacity, whichever is greater. In determining the amount that a former employee is able to earn, the Commission will have regard to the same factors as it would have regard to in determining the amount that a current employee is able to earn.

These factors include the amount that the employee is actually earning; the amount that the employee would be earning if he or she had remained in, or accepted an offer of, suitable employment; and if the employee failed to seek suitable employment, the amount that, having regard to the state of the labour market, the employee could reasonably expect to earn if he or she had sought work.

The amendments to the Act that would be made by this Bill are expected to result in a saving to Comcare of approximately $3m in a full year. Additional savings will be made by the two administering authorities, Telecom Australia and Australia Post. The amendments would come into operation on a date to be proclaimed and claimants will be advised of the possible reduction in their benefits, as a result of these amendments, in order to minimise their impact. The amendment to section 5 of the Act would remove any doubt that non-police staff of the Australian Federal Police are covered by the Act. Prior to the beginning of this year, non-police staff were appointed under the Public Service Act and, as public servants, were covered by the Compensation Act.

Since then, non-police staff have been appointed under the Australian Federal Police Act and a question has arisen whether those new appointees fall within the definition of `employee' in section 5 of the Compensation Act. The amendment will make it clear that the Act does apply to non-police staff of the Australian Federal Police. Although most of the appointments will not occur until July 1990, some have been made already. Accordingly, it has been necessary to make this amendment retrospective to 1 January 1990 to make sure that the people concerned have been covered from the date of their appointment. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment Bill. I do not intend to detain the House for the normal period allotted. That is a good warning to any of my colleagues who may need to gather. I simply say that the two amendments proposed by the Government are sensible.
