SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like other speakers, I have been caught a little bit unawares by the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment Bill being brought on for debate at this time, but I am very pleased to speak on it nonetheless. It is important that we alter the Comcare Act as is required, as the Government sees fit to do from time to time, in regard to retired Commonwealth employees' benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly concerned about other aspects of Comcare's administration, which I would like to talk about for a moment. They relate to the administration by Telecom Australia of Comcare. In my electorate I have received quite a number of complaints from ex-Commonwealth employees who have worked for Telecom and who have had severe repetitive strain injury and whose cases have been dealt with unfairly by Telecom. There has been a lack of trust in the dealings of Telecom with those employees. That is something we need to look at in legislation that may come before the House in the form of future amendments to the Comcare Act.

I am glad to see the Minister for Fin- ance (Mr Willis) who represents the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) making some amendments today with regard to retired Commonwealth workers, but there are also very good reasons for looking at the way the Act is administered by statutory authorities. If people are injured at work the idea of Comcare and the Act itself is to ensure that they are properly rehabilitated and given every opportunity to seek that rehabilitation before being compensated.

It concerns me that a lot of the people who have raised this problem are women who have been working in, perhaps, the switchboard area where obviously there is quite a lot of repetitive strain injury occurring. Regrettably, they are not being offered opportunities for rehabilitation. There are other ways that Telecom can look after these people through light duties where these exist. With voice-operated switchboards, they can also now be given jobs in this area because, of course, they still possess all of the expertise that they previously had, but are unable to use their arms and wrists in the same way. Some repetitive strain injury and over use conditions are exacerbated by air-conditioning. Honourable members on this side of the House may wish to think about that as they work in air-conditioned buildings, such as this one, for long per- iods of time.

My experience with Telecom on compensation and rehabilitation matters has been quite unsatisfactory. I have written to Telecom several times in an endeavour to ensure that it administers the Act in the way I think it should be, allowing people to have an opportunity of satisfactory rehabilitation before condemning them to a life of reliance on compensation outside the work force. This is obviously an unsatisfactory arrangement for the employees and for the statutory authority which, under the Comcare Act, has to pick up the bill completely.

There has been a tendency to rule people out of compensation on the basis of one medical opinion when that medical opinion suits the employer-in this case Telecom. On the other hand, injured employees are made to go to as many as five, six, seven or sometimes more doctors when their claim is supported. But as they find one who does not support them, then it is that doctor's medical evidence that is selected and used in favour of the employer and to question the employee's right to compensation or rehabilitation. The other doctors' opinions are not taken into account. This is a very serious problem which I was intending to raise in a grievance debate and I will refer to it again with more specific information on another occasion.

Comcare has within its realm the ability to transfer to statutory authorities the administration after a short period of time-that is, two years. That two years is coming to an end shortly. I wanted to make that point-not to the Minister here as I realise it is not his portfolio responsibility entirely-and draw it to the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) who now has responsibility for these types of Bills. I also draw it to the attention of Senator Richardson. It should also be drawn to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), given that Telecom comes under his portfolio responsibility. Much of what it does in this area of compensation is of concern to many members of parliament. Similar problems do not seem to be occurring with Australia Post. Therefore, it is a matter of concern to this House.

The Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment Bill, as the Minister has said, amends the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act to allow the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees, which is Comcare, to take account of the amount that former employees are able to earn in calculating their rate of weekly benefits. It will ensure that the Act applies to non-police staff members of the Australian Federal Police appointed since 1 January.

We on this side of the House thoroughly support the Comcare legislation. The alterations to it, I believe, would have been done with sufficient consultation with people concerned and I am sure would be assisting their arrangements in their retirement from the Commonwealth's employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many workers in the community who are very concerned-those of us who spend our time in this place are constantly assailed by our many constituents who express concern-about compensation and the various issues that relate to the way in which they are protected in the work force. One of the most meaningful things that any government or any legislator can do is improve the circumstances of those who are needing compensation because of work related problems and injuries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment Bill, as it relates to Comcare, is very important. There has been some concern expressed, as the Opposition spokesman suggested, about the employees' groups concerning this fact and the able to earn clause and how it will relate to their actual payments. I share the concern expressed by the shadow spokesman on this area because these sorts of calculations will necessarily be subjective. The judgments on whether or not a person is able to earn a certain salary and the prospects that they have are not easy to make. There is seldom a black or white answer as to what one's capability is.

If one looks at the sort of injuries that occur at work, one will see that the area of concern that relates to compensation most often seems to be back injuries. The area where I would say the medical profession struggles most in the treatment of compensation cases is the area of back injuries. One finds time and again people who have had serious back injuries for long periods of time coming before medical boards and medical specialists. They have their cases reassessed, they work for short periods and they have a relapse. These sorts of cases create log-jams for the medical profession-certainly before legal boards and certainly before those who wish to provide compensation.

I think that the medical profession would agree that it is an area which is very badly treated. It is an area where we find continual difficulty in establishing what is the best way of treating these people. What is their capability to work? Do they have the possibility of being able to earn substantial salaries? Are they capable of working full time? Perhaps they have to change the type of duties in which they are involved. Those sorts of dilemmas face those involved with determining compensation and ability to work claims time and again.

One of the most important aspects of this-I have been speaking over the last couple of years with those involved in treating back injuries in particular-is that the critical part of the treatment of such injuries is rehabilitation. I think this stems from a cultural thing or perhaps something that is built up over a long period of time. I spoke yesterday in the grievance debate about this issue, about the aspect that there are too many injured workers expecting the medical profession-expecting doctors-to be able to solve the problem. They expect a quick fix and an easy cure.

There is no simple solution, particularly with back injuries which form the bulk of our compensation cases. A well-known philosopher, H. L. Mencken, said that for every complex problem there is a simple solution, and it is usually wrong. That is the case when it comes to back injuries. It is clear that the most important component for dealing with these problems is rehabilitation, which means that patients have to get off their backsides and work at getting themselves right again. The ethos, the cultural belief, out there in our community is that there can be a quick fix or an easy solution to the problem; that Paul Ehrlich's magic bullet can solve--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like the economy.
—It is exactly the same, and there are members on the other side who trumpet the suggestion that they have the solution.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Howard interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There are members on the other side, but not the honourable member for Bennelong. He is a consistent and rational talker on economic issues in this place, so I would never charge him with having made these claims, but there are members who suggest that there is a simple solution to our economic problems.

—I remind the honourable member that that is not the subject of the Bill before the House. I also remind the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Menzies of the same situation.

—I was misled by the honourable member for Bennelong, who is always drawn to this place when I am on my feet. When we come to dealing with compensation cases, and particularly when one is talking about the bulk of these cases which represent back problems, then the solution is rehabilitation. We are not willing very often to tell the patient in these cases that really they have to do a lot of hard work to get themselves back into the able to earn category. The able to earn category is the part of this legislation that those within the employee groups are concerned about, because there will necessarily be subjective judgments made about their capacity to earn and their ability to be productive members of the work force. Whether or not they are going to be producing effectively, whether they are able to return to their former level of activity or are only capable of working at a lower rate-what we might call light duties-or whether they need to be trained in another way are necessarily subjective judgments.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no simple way one can look at a patient's X-ray and say, `We can see this anomaly on the X-ray, and this means that they will not be capable of lifting a wheelbarrow full of cement'; or, `We can look at this X-ray and say that this nurse will not be able to move a sick patient in the hospital bed and, therefore, she has to work in another area or accept different duties'. What is very clear is that some people who have beautiful looking X-rays suffer severe pain and other people who have rotten looking X-rays are capable of doing very hard and difficult labours.

Those sorts of judgments are made by doctors, and in the end what we need to have is some cultural change whereby people accept that an important part of the process of their treatment is their rehabilitation and the amount of work and effort that they can provide. If that means that one has to get into the swimming pool and swim up and down the pool-as I know honourable members of this House do, although not necessarily those with back injuries-then that is the sort of effort that needs to be provided and the intensive treatment that can bring about a rehabilitation and a return to one's former working capacity. I believe that it is important that that point be made, and employee and employer groups and, indeed, the medical profession have to accept that that is part of their role.

What we find, of course, is that people get a back injury and find themselves on the medical merry-go-round. They arrive in the doctor's office and he makes an assessment of the problem as best he can. Unfortunately, the general practitioner learns very little about the treatment of complex back injuries, so the patient ends up after a few weeks of physiotherapy and the doctor failing to solve the problem being sent on to the orthopaedic surgeon. The orthopaedic surgeon likes to sharpen the blade and is thinking about the doctor-dollar relationship, but before he does that-and in most cases it would be precipitous of him to recommend surgery too early-the patient might be sent off to the neurologist, because the neurologist needs to make an assessment of the particular neurological deficit that might exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then the lawyers come in.

—They are like sharks in the water tank, just snapping away there. The patient continues to have physiotherapy, again expecting the magic bullet. The physiotherapist provides magical ultrasonic treatment and various exercise programs, but after six months the problem remains. Sometimes the patient then goes off to the pain clinic, and all sorts of other treatments are suggested and projected such as epidural injections, which are very controversial at the moment, as honourable members will have heard, and eventually the patient comes back to the orthopaedic surgeon or the neurosurgeon. If anyone is listening, I suggest that neurosurgeons are a better bet because they tend to deal more kindly with nerves and neural tissue.

SPEECH.PARA: Then the decision is made: is it surgery or not? In most cases we do not need that option. It is very clear when surgery is the solution of choice. That sort of medical merry-go-round goes on for years and years, and it is very frustrating for patients. It is impossible to judge what is actually happening. In the end, the case is decided by the level of pain. Of course, nobody can make a judgment on that except the patient himself, and that causes great frustration for the patient, great depression, a loss of confidence and, certainly very often in family relationships, a loss of the classical relationship that exists between the wage-earner and the rest of the family group. The problems are indeed considerable.

This legislation enables those who are receiving compensation payments to have factored into those payments the other amounts of capital that they are able to earn. Indeed, it factors in superannuation payments that they may be receiving. If one looks at Comcare and its efficiency, we find, as was mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech, that over the time of its operation it has been very successful in curtailing expenditure-and, indeed, savings in a full year of about $20m are significant.

I think it is an area in which the Government has made some progress. If this legislation, which is supported by the Opposition, can tighten up the proposals and can make more efficient the way in which compensation payments are made and compensation treatment is provided, then the progress we have made so far will have been useful. There are factors that need to be taken into account which are, as I have already said, subjective. The savings that this legislation bring about are about $3m in a full year. Many would suggest that there is a lot of pain in this decision for very little gain.

What we are about in this place is trying to make more efficient those things that we are responsible for in Commonwealth expenditure; and, although in the context of the whole Budget $3m seems a very small amount, it is a very significant saving. We need to be very aware of the fact that every $3m that we can save means that we can perhaps provide a better service in our education system; it means that perhaps we can provide better funding for our hospitals; and it means that we can provide better services for those who are in need of assistance through the Commonwealth. It is important that we target our Commonwealth expenditure. I believe that this legislation, while only a small part of that, is something that needs to be continued by us.

I conclude by saying that there will be a reduction in the duration of claims as a result of this legislation and the average premium rate should reduce. Those things are further indicative of the fact that we have become more efficient in the way in which Comcare is structured and the way in which payments are meted out. I believe that is a significant advance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Winston Churchill once said, `If you want me to speak for five minutes, give me a week's notice'. If you want me to speak for an hour, then give me a minute's notice.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with great pleasure that I support the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment Bill, which is an important component, as the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) and the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) have made clear, of making sure either that people can get back into the work force or are at least able to cope while they are not in the work force-in this case people employed by the Commonwealth. It is interesting that almost every training course that is now adopted by the Commonwealth Employment Service, or Skillshare in this case-particularly the farm courses-involves training in safety. It is not so long ago that I presented certificates to the sawmill at Bega, which had the best safety record in the region. At that presentation I noticed that quite a number of the people who received certificates had fingers missing. If we go to any sawmill today we will find that the younger people have all their fingers. This is because of the training programs and the rehabilitation and preventive work that the honourable member for Perth talked about-implemented not only in training sessions, but also on the job. It is all extremely important.

This Bill is making sure that people receiving assistance in rehabilitation receive it in a just and fair way. Some of the amendments involved ensure that the Act applies to non-police staff members of the Australian Federal Police who have been appointed since 1 January 1990 when certain new employment arrangements took effect. Others allow the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees to have regard to the amount that former employees are able to earn in suitable employment. The amount that former employees are able to earn would reduce their entitlement to compensation under the Act. Provisions of this nature are normal in workers compensation legislation.

The Act currently provides for reductions in the benefits payable to current employees who are capable of earning income from suitable employment. The non-inclusion of an able to earn test in the provisions relating to the calculation of weekly benefits payable to former employees was the result of an omission which occurred in the development of the Act. It is estimated that the amendments to the Act will be made clear by this Bill and will save the Commission approximately $3m in a full year. Additional savings will be made by the two administering authorities-Telecom Australia and Australia Post.

The legislation is an extremely important move to ensure that full application is given to the original intention of Comcare. Under subclause 2-I am sure that I will not get a further opportunity in the committee stage of the bill to discuss these matters, so I will discuss them very briefly now-the retrospective commencement of this provision would ensure that all staff members of the Australian Federal Police, including those who have been appointed since 1 January under the new arrangements provided for in the Australian Federal Police Act, would be entitled to claim compensation under the Act for any injuries suffered by them from that date. It is with great pleasure that I support the legislation and its role in the full development of adequate and caring policies for people who come under Comcare.

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith the following motion:
That the House of Representatives-
(1) authorises the broadcasting by ABC TV of Question Time for a trial period from 21 August to 18 October 1990;

(2) the distribution of the broadcast between the two Houses be in accordance with the distribution of the radio broadcast, provided the Senate is broadcast on no less than three days in any two week sitting period; and
(3) authorises the broadcasting by television stations of excerpts of proceedings in accordance with the following conditions:

(a) Access to the proceedings of the House of Representatives for the recording and broadcasting of excerpts of proceedings is subject to an undertaking to observe, and to compliance with, the following conditions.
(b) Recordings and broadcasts may be made only from Channel 1 on the house monitoring system.

(c) Broadcasts of excerpts shall be used only for the purposes of fair and accurate reports of proceedings, and shall not be used for: (1) political party advertising or election campaigns; (2) satire and ridicule; or (3) commercial sponsorship or commercial advertising.

(d) That the conditions contained in paragraph (c) be referred to the Procedure Committee for inquiry and report by 21 August 1990, and that these orders have effect until altered by a further order of the House of Representatives in relation to the report of the Procedure Committee.
(e) Reports of proceedings shall be such as to provide a balanced presentation of differing views.
(f) Excerpts of proceedings which are subsequently withdrawn may be broadcast only if the withdrawal is also reported.
(g) Debate on a motion for the adjournment of the House of Representatives shall not be broadcast.
(h) The instructions of the Speaker of the House of Representatives or his delegates in respect of the broadcasting of excerpts, which are not inconsistent with these conditions, shall be observed.

I have drawn attention in recent days in this Parliament to an important element of the last election result, and that is the visible plague on both our houses evidenced in that result. The fact that the Government achieved only 39 3/4 per cent of the primary vote and the Opposition 43 per cent of the primary vote indicates significantly that there is a great deal of disillusionment and disenchantment with the two major parties in the eyes of the electorate. People are justifiably cynical about the standing and performance of politicians in the two major parties.

I believe a large part of that, an important element of that, has been our performance in this place. It is against that background of our desire to raise parliamentary standards that we bring forward the motion at this time for the televising of Parliament, initially on a trial basis, and hopefully on a more significant and extended basis so that the people of Australia can be the judge of our parliamentary performance.

I think it is instructive in this regard to draw attention to an opinion poll done by the Morgan Research group which appeared in this week's Bulletin magazine which showed that only 13 per cent of the Australian people believe that we are ethical and honest. In the list we ranked well behind pharmacists, doctors, dentists and school teachers.

TALK.START.PARA: —But above journalists.

—We even ranked behind television reporters. Noticeably, we did rank somewhat above journalists. The point is that we are held in significant public disregard to a large extent because of our performance in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate wants us to lift our game. The people want to get value for their money. They read today in the newspapers that we are voting ourselves an increase in salary. They want to ensure that they get value for money against the very significant salaries that are paid to people in this House. Electors know that we have got real problems in Australia. They know the magnitude of those problems-they see the vacant shops and failed businesses; they see the data on personal bankruptcies reaching record levels and small to medium sized business failures reaching record levels. They know that high interest rates are a principal cause of that. The people know the magnitude of our balance of payments and debt problems. They want those problems and those issues and the policy solutions associated with them debated in this House. They do not want Members of this House to spend an inordinate amount of their time playing games, acting like a circus and appearing like a bearpit; they want us to get on with the job.

One of the best ways to focus the attention of the electorate on the extent to which the parliamentary process has been abused is to open it up for television broadcasting. The people want a degree of professionalism from us that they expect in other aspects of their lives. For example, they want Question Time to actually be Question Time. They want questions asked and want questions answered; they do not want Question Time being used as an opportunity, by way of dorothy dixers, to tip buckets on the Opposition. They want to see Ministers stand up and do their jobs. They want to expose those Ministers when they cannot do their jobs; when they cannot answer those questions.

Members of the public also expect that matters of public importance and other motions will be seriously debated in this House, not in circumstances where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Treasurer (Mr Keating) leave the Parliament, leaving the defence of their Government and its performance to some new or lower level backbencher rather than taking the debate themselves. While people in the gallery might be impressed on occasions by the performance of key Government Ministers and the erudite way in which they heap buckets of abuse on us, and while they might be impressed that the Treasurer calls the manufacturing sector in Australia a spittoon, the people of Australia will not be impressed by that sort of behaviour. They will not be impressed by Ministers who are visibly not doing their jobs in Question Time, in more general debates, in matters of public importance, in ministerial statements, in Opposition responses, and so on.

The people of Australia would also be dead unimpressed with the extent to which legislation is mishandled in this place; the extent to which legislation is guillotined through this Parliament, as it was recently. We offered to come back for an extra week and to spend the time doing the job. But no, 34 Bills were rammed through this place in a day and a half. Many of those Bills will be full of errors because they have not had sufficient time spent on them for scrutiny and examination. That would be clearly exposed by the televising of Parliament to the people of Australia. They could monitor the attendance of some of us. They could monitor the extent to which we represent our electorates and a host of other ways in which they find it difficult to get a handle on our performance at the present time.

So I put it to honourable members that today there is a very important and urgent need to provide the people of Australia with the opportunity to be the direct judges of our parliamentary performance. I was interested in an interview on the World Today at lunchtime with Mr Austin Mitchell, a Labour member of parliament who is chairman of the all-party committee on televising parliament in Britain. He concluded, after a number of remarks, that parliamentarians tended to take a more active interest in their job, and visibly so. He said:
. . . we are actually more influential because governments don't actually listen to words, they listen to the people.

The people will have the opportunity to monitor our performance openly and directly if we expose ourselves to the scrutiny of television by opening this House and its proceedings to televising on a trial basis.

Yesterday evening in the Senate, a motion was successfully passed to offer the opportunity for the televising of Senate Question Time on a trial basis. This provides a very important opportunity for us to issue a challenge to the Prime Minister and the Government in respect to the lower House to match that opportunity that has been provided in the Senate. It is a very important issue which is on the minds of many people in Australia at the present time. I urge the Government to take up the opportunity that has been provided by the lead shown in the Senate yesterday, to match it in the lower House, at least in the August sitting, as a trial move and hopefully to then extend that procedure right across all parliamentary proceedings in an unlimited way.

This is not a new idea. There has been a lot of support for it over the years. A joint committee of the Parliament has supported it. I gather that both Presiding Officers of the Parliament have indicated that they would approve a trial period. Our coalition party room has certainly approved it on a trial basis. I have heard, and I understand, that at least an early review of it by the Caucus approved it. The key question is: why has it not happened? What does the Government have to hide? Who is it that does not want the Parliament to be exposed to public scrutiny?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the Treasurer.

—It could well be the Treasurer. It might be that he is a bit sensitive about his performance in the Parliament being exposed to the people of Australia. I strongly urge the Government to accept the thrust of this motion, given all the expensive equipment that has been built into this Parliament House and the opportunity that exists almost at the turn of a switch, and to accept the challenge.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communication)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am reluctant to do so as I rarely raise points of order. However, the Leader of the House is continually misrepresenting the Opposition's position. We did not indicate to the Government that we were opposed to televising Parliament.
—There is no point of order.

—Opposition members indicated it to themselves and we got to hear about it. SPEECH.PARA: The reason this proposal is before us now is that the Opposition is subject to pressure. The Opposition has discovered that a section of the Press Gallery, quite reasonably pursuing the interests of its section of the electronic media, feels it would be helpful for it to be able to get access to excerpts of Question Time for the purpose of broadcasts on the nightly news. That is not an ignoble objective. It may indeed be an objective that ultimately the Government comes to agree with.

But what those people are concerned not to do is to provide an opportunity for people to see the whole functioning of Parliament throughout our daily toil. Why do they not want to provide that? I am afraid the answer is that, no matter what the Opposition may say about a requirement for us to up standards in this place and provide a spectacle that people will find elevating, uplifting and informative, on the whole people will choose not to watch it. On the whole, they will take the view, as they have with the radio broadcasts of Parliament, that this is a piece of advice during the day on the conduct of government, a spectacle that they will feel themselves not in the least bit deprived of if they do not see it.

Let us be honest about the pressures that come on us in this place. No evidence has been presented that there is a massive public demand for televising Parliament. There is a substantial demand above us in the Gallery that there ought to be a televising of Parliament, or excerpts of it, but there is no evidence to suggest that there is any public demand. We have only the evidence of what happens on radio broadcasts, and that is that we get a very paltry audience. If people are going to vote with their ears-the number of ears than can be counted listening in to our broadcast at any time-we will have to say that those who want access to broadcasting of Parliament either by radio or television represent a very small proportion of the Australian population.

Let us not get round to this point that we ought to consider the subject of broadcasting because there is a massive upsurge of democratic opinion swelling and rolling across Lake Burley Griffin towards us; there is a picket being conducted outside Parliament House demanding that people be allowed to listen to us and, above all, see us. There is no such argument taking place in the public.

What we are into here is the opportunity for a bit of self-indulgence and a bit of playing to the Gallery on our part. That is what we are being invited to do. In our view, that is not a sufficient reason to hurry consideration of this proposal through the Parliament at this point.

When the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) presented his argument he went through a plethora of accusations about what is done in the Parliament, with the implication than if Parliament is broadcast there will be absolutely terrific management of the economy; if Parliament is broadcast, all of a sudden people's behaviour will change dramatically; and if Parliament is broadcast there is going to be cure-all to all the great issues of public debate today. Basically those were the sorts of claims that he put forward. Those are, to say the least, tendentious opinions.

If we could all say that perfect management of the economy would result from the broadcast of Parliament, we could well find ourselves adopting this proposal with alacrity. Indeed, if this fact had become generally known, I dare say we would have been sprinting into this place to put this matter to a vote as quickly as possible. However, rational analysis would suggest that that is most unlikely to follow.

I suppose we might get a guarantee from the Leader of the Opposition that if Parliament is broadcast we will not in future get questions about the operations on Ministers, questions about whether or not Ministers are under death threats-that was the sort of question that was asked the other day-for the purpose of elevating Parliament and this chamber and making sure that all the great national public issues of the day are being properly considered in this place. Do we think that if we broadcast Parliament such questions would cease in Question Time? I suspect not.

When these matters have been debated in the past, generally there has been a section of the Parliament which has held the view that what is likely to happen is that everything in Parliament will become set piece; that there will be set piece opportunities for debate in which Parliament is treated simply as a sounding board and not a deliberative chamber that is fine. That is as least as likely an outcome. I do not think that anybody who has analysed the speeches of Parliament-as I did when I was a student of history and politics-could say that there was not a substantial change in style in the way in which matters were deliberated in this place after radio broadcasting compared with those prior to broadcasting. One cannot say whether it was due to that directly.

There are enough issues here, having received new advice on the matter from the Opposition as to its attitude in the last fortnight, for us to want to consider that in some more detail before arriving at our conclusions. Our conclusion to this point is that we have an open mind on it and we wish to deliberate further, but not at this time. DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL 1990[COGNATE BILL:BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Beazley:.
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before debate is resumed on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate covering this Bill and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) be allowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when I was speaking to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2), which amend the Broadcasting Act, I said that the revision in the form of those two Bills is really the forerunner to the broader review of the Broadcasting Act which the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) has outlined and upon which discussion will continue.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this legislation arises from the state of confusion about the economic viability of much of our broadcast industry. These two Bills reflect that concern in the public interest provision and in their recognition of the need for proper constraints on the role of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). There is to be a streamlining of those provisions that have not worked adequately and a removal, at least in part, of some of the backlog that has occurred within the Broadcasting Tribunal's activities. As I said last night before we moved on to other matters, the issues concerning the worth of the public interest and the desire of the community to encourage a viable Australian broadcasting industry are paramount to what lies behind these Bills and the broader review that will follow.

As I indicated last night, reference was made earlier in the debate to the question of limits on foreign ownership. There is no doubt that in the general community there is great concern about the need to encourage real Australian involvement, participation and equity right through the industry. The problem should not be put solely at the feet of the Government. Some would suggest that, in view of the problems of the entrepreneurs in the business, the Government should be forced into bailing them out following their excesses and actions which have not been condoned or in any way encouraged by the Government. If one talks to people, as members of parliament do-I certainly talk to the people of my electorate of Parramatta-one finds that they are concerned to ensure that we preserve our television industry and our television productions. Because of problems in the radio industry it is just as important that we preserve the effective operation of the broadcast industry as a whole.

I think the measures contained in the two Bills which streamline the ABT and remove some of its unnecessary powers are desirable and set a framework for positive change and positive steps towards the review that will come forward as part of a broader package later in the year. I commend the Government, and the Minister in particular, for having the foresight and the courage to proceed with that broader review. A lot of concern has been expressed about the ownership question, the economic viability of the relative operators and so forth. I commend the Government for its fortitude in proceeding to preserve our industry. The people in the industry-as opposed to a few entrepreneurs-want to get back to a level playing field. They want a more balanced approach and they want the public interest to be properly preserved and maintained. I believe that this legislation sets the scene for that to take place.

This legislation changes the share transaction approval process. The change in the definition of `prescribed interest' will free up the role of the ABT where it is appropriate to do that. The extension of the maximum period for the licence arrangements allows more flexibility so that the Tribunal's role is clearly defined, much of the backlog is removed and much of the typing up of matters before the Tribunal-something the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) referred to last night-will cease. All people who have an interest in this field-particularly the various consumer organisations, unions and so forth-take the view that changes of this sort are positive changes. They recognise that some of the regulations have been allowed to tie up the process too tightly and have therefore created the backlogs that were referred to by the right honourable member for New England.

This legislation redresses many of the broadcast policy decisions of the last decade or so. The 1981 provisions in particular were objected to by many people when they were introduced. It was felt that those provisions were creating problems that should have been addressed more adequately by the then Fraser Government. At least now we have taken a very positive and tangible step to ensure that that situation can be remedied. The provisions outlined in the Bill and in the Minister's second reading speech represent perhaps only an interim step in that change, but I think it is a very positive and constructive one.

I can only say that, for the people who live in areas such as the electorates in western Sydney, the changes that are contained in this legislation will be important because they will give the people the right and the opportunity to contribute positively to licence renewal questions which are of great concern. As with a number of other areas, we need more information and more public dissemination of material through the broadcasting system to ensure that community needs are met.

Under this legislation, radio stations such as 2WS in western Sydney, which I mentioned last night, will be able to have their needs properly addressed as part of the broader review. This legislation starts the process rolling in a very constructive way. I acknowledge the Minister's commitment that he has outlined on a number of occasions, and I know that the Government's agenda for that whole process of change-in particular the decision that has been taken on the 20 per cent foreign ownership provision-is in the collective interest of not only the community in my area but also all of those people who have concern for the diversity and the dynamics of the Australian broadcasting industry.

This legislation should be taken on board and warmly acknowledged by all. It should be seen as a very positive step for those people who obtain their livelihoods from the industry and who at the same time are a part-and indeed proud to be a part-of ensuring that the democratic process is furthered by an adequate and proper broadcast policy which encourages the dynamics, encourages change and is flexible enough to allow the ABT to encourage and permit change. At the same time, the legislation ensures that the Australian national interest is fully honoured and enhanced. That has been the clear objective of the Government, and I am very pleased to lend my strong support to the Bills before the House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I say that I found the contributions of all honourable members who have participated in this debate quite interesting. There were some with which I did not agree.
—You should be standing somewhere else.
—No, I am quite happy to stand here. I do not want to argue.
—Aren't you representing the Minister?
—The Standing Orders provide that a member is entitled to speak from his seat or the dispatch box.

—I thank the honourable member opposite for advising me where I might sit or might not sit. I am quite happy to stand where I am at this present stage. I commend the contributions made by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott). I found the rebuttal of the arguments put forward by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), by the honourable member for Parramatta and the honourable member for Chifley-notwithstanding the contributions made by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow)-to quite succinctly put to rest the concerns which have been raised by the honourable member for Menzies and the honourable member for New England.

SPEECH.PARA: The sort of attack which was made upon the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) by the right honourable member for New England was not necessary-indeed, it was misplaced. In the context of the contribution made by the honourable member for Menzies, I would like to address in some further detail some of the questions which he raised during the course of the debate.

One thing needs to be made clear about the Broadcasting Amendment Bill and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2). Together, those Bills provide for much more efficient and effective regulation. I know that the honourable member for Menzies in the course of the debate yesterday admitted that he thought there were many aspects of this legislation that he supported. However, I was a bit amazed with the amendment relating to the first piece of legislation, which in my view sells short the legislation rather dramatically.

What he ought to understand is that the first Bill gives the ABT effective remedies as an alternative to licence revocation. It appears that the Opposition would do nothing about this situation, so that if the licensee was manifestly unsuitable the ABT would have the opportunity of doing nothing about it or deprive viewers of their services by depriving the licensee of his or her licence. To me, that-not the legislation which is before the Parliament-seems to be draconian.

He has argued that the Bill is draconian and gives unnecessary powers. But he cannot be arguing that the ABT should have lesser powers. Surely he is not arguing that the ABT should not have some discretionary powers that, for example, it should be able to order remedial action or to give protective directions or order divestment. Is he saying that there ought to be two alternatives: nothing or revocation? I do not believe that that is in the best interests of the Australian broadcasting industry and it is certainly not a position which is supported by this Government.

Efficiency is the key to the second Bill. That is acknowledged by the Opposition and it removes unnecessary red tape and paper work. Its measures will save the ABT and investors much time and money and allow the ABT to focus on important issues such as control. Even the Opposition concedes that that is a good thing.

The honourable member for Menzies said that yesterday. I think it is important that we see, as the honourable member for Parramatta quite rightly pointed out, the impact that this will have on the services which are undertaken by the ABT. It seems to me that this will allow the ABT to address itself to important licensing matters and share transactions that may have a substantive impact on the broadcasting community.

The second Bill is also essential in maintaining the current services to the public. It allows the continuation of legitimate networking arrangements that keep existing metropolitan and regional services on the air. It will allow more regional viewers to receive the same services as metropolitan viewers. The honourable member for Capricornia said to me yesterday and, as have a number of people who have spoken in this debate, pointed out the advantages that this legislation has brought to regional viewers. Those advantages should not be discounted.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro pointed out the dramatic advantages that aggregation has provided for the constituents in his electorate. I am looking forward to the impact of equalisation in some areas of regional Australia. I find the criticisms which are made of the legislation by the Opposition in this context again to be misplaced. I do not believe it understands the contents of the legislation or the importance of the moves being put in place by the Government.

There are provisions in the No. 2 Bill which provide exemptions for the breach of the 60 per cent metropolitan reach television limit and associated cross media limits which might arise as an incidental result of program supply under television networking agreements. Related provisions in the Bill ensure that special ABT approval is not required under section 89a of the Act as a result of the radio or television program supply agreement or agreements between licensees and copyright collection agencies. These amendments have been drafted in response to advice given by the Solicitor-General to the ABT. Before that advice was provided, the ABT had administered the Broadcasting Act on the basis that legitimate program arrangements would not constitute control for the purposes of the Act.

The ABT has not required essential approval under section 89a to participate in the benefits of relevant affiliated licences. The Opposition has moved to strike out all provisions in the Bill which provide exemptions from program supply arrangements. A closer analysis of the claims made by the Opposition reveals fundamental misconceptions about the nature of the proposed amendments. The Opposition has claimed, for example, that the networking amendments are not necessary. The amendments, in fact, are needed to remove serious legal doubt about existing network arrangements to metropolitan areas and the extension of commercial television services to regional areas under the equalisation program. The 60 per cent reach limit prevents common ownership or control of commercial television licences in each metropolitan area in Australia.

Unlike the Opposition, the Government is not prepared to jeopardise the continuance of existing networking arrangements to affiliate in metropolitan areas such as Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide. The Government is also not prepared to jeopardise the continued extension of regional television services under the aggregation program. The Opposition has argued that the networking exemptions have made the 60 per cent reach limit obsolete. The provisions do not, however, provide a blanket extension to networking licensees in terms of any control which can be exercised other than as an incidental result of the supply of programs to a metropolitan regional licensee. Nor do they allow network licensees to own additional metropolitan or regional stations in excess of the 60 per cent limit.

The exemptions in this Bill would also not apply to any control exercised by a network supplier over the amount of local or other non-network programming which could be broadcast by the regional licensee. The rights of a regional licensee to make independent decisions on programming policy are not restricted by any provisions in this Bill.

The Opposition has also claimed that the networking amendments would remove the ABT supervision of networking arrangements to prevent exploitation of regional licensees. The ABT has power to examine and take action against any exploitation of any regional licensees through networking in particular through its licence condition and renewal powers. The requirement in the Bill that television networking agreements be in writing and lodged with the ABT will provide a basis for ABT examination of any powers of control which might be exercised by a network supplier, other than as an incidental result of the supply of programs.

There is no need to impose an additional regulatory burden as proposed by the Opposition for every networking agreement to receive prior ABT approval through a formal inquiry process. This Opposition proposal is entirely inconsistent with its complaints that the ABT is being given too many regulatory powers at a time when those powers should be reduced. I suggest to the honourable member for Menzies that if he had examined the position which the Opposition has been adopting, he would note that inconsistency. The Opposition has expressed concern, and the honourable member for Menzies did it in the course of his contribution yesterday, about the effect of amendments on a court action in the Federal Court. As already indicated, these amendments are necessary so that the existing network arrangements in metropolitan areas can continue and additional commercial television services can be offered to regional viewers. Litigation should not be used as an excuse to prevent the Parliament resolving uncertainties in the law in a way that simply confirms longstanding Government policy. It is appropriate that this legislation should contain these amendments.

The honourable member for Menzies sought an assurance on the issue of foreign ownership. The Government's position needs to be understood very clearly. It is time to dispel some of the myths that have surrounded this issue. I just put the issue in context. The Australian Labor Party's policy has been very clear and concise. The issue has been addressed in the legislation since 1956. The present moves being made address, by and large, those changes made in the legislation by the Opposition in 1981. Those amendments allowed foreign investors to hold an aggregate up to and including 50 per cent of a holding company of an Australian broadcasting licensee provided no foreign individual acquired actual control or had more than a 15 per cent direct or indirect deemed control in the licensee. This allows very high levels of foreign interest in Australian broadcasters to be achieved through various contrived schemes. This proposal will introduce proportional tracing of interests for the purpose of determining the aggregate level of foreign interest.

This method of tracing deems a personal company which holds a proportion of the shares of another company with broadcasting interests, either directly as a licensee or indirectly through another company with direct or indirect interests in a licensee, to hold a similar proportion of that other company's broadcasting interests. For example, company A, which owns 50 per cent of the shares in company B which owns 100 per cent of licensee C, is deemed to have a 50 per cent interest in the licensee, 50 per cent of 100 per cent of licensee C. This will ensure that interests held in holding companies or in remote companies are counted in determining the aggregate levels of foreign interest. I stress that the Bill will still outlaw any arrangement, including loan arrangements, which give actual control to a foreign person.

We actually find WIN television winning the news ratings in Wollongong and along the south coast. We actually find Capital winning the news ratings in Canberra and the local area around here and towards Cooma and Bombala and Jindabyne. We would probably find the people who are very interested in the local news doing so on Prime rather than the other two stations in the Dubbo-Orange area. There will be some trend away, depending on the competition and the money that people put into it.

There has been some evidence that the stations have not tried too hard to take news from the existing station. They have tried to provide other competition, but this has not worked particularly well. It is interesting to note in the Canberra sub-region that Prime, which was showing news at a quarter to six, has changed it to six o'clock to compete with the other networks. There is pretty strong evidence that it is catering for local news on all the channels for aggregation. There is also strong evidence that we cannot put undue pressure on them to spend money without its returning a dividend of some sort.

I know that we have to look at aggregation and how it will work in the rest of the country. We intend to provide people throughout the nation with as many alternatives as possible but we must make sure that people have not only variety but also quality. We have to draw a balance somewhere. The honourable member for Menzies has drawn the line differently from the way we would, taking the view that we must provide some incentive for the networks to work towards aggregation.

In this region aggregation generally has been extremely well received, for instance, in my electorate of Eden-Monaro. There are people who have been able to gain not only new television stations but also a variety in what they watch. For instance, local television stations-let us say WIN-are giving time to towns such as Queanbeyan. It does not have the audience in Canberra, but it will go to Queanbeyan and do a lot more there than perhaps the others, and then people think that WIN is giving them a fair go. Prime was quite well watched in the Bombala area. It may well be that Prime took the trouble to go there because it was interested in Bombala and Jindabyne. It was, to some extent, a commercial decision.

Capital has tried to meet that competition. On the coast the regional network which links with the Nine network still has some advantage at the moment. There has to be an acknowledgment that the Nine network is generally a popular network throughout Australia. Along the south-east coast there is a fairly strong identification with Nine. There have been some problems, particularly for Capital and Prime, in getting into those pockets with UHF television. It is much easier for VHF television to reach those areas. That is not because there is any problem with the strength of the signal, but if there is not line of sight-in other words, contact-between the receiver and the transmitting area there are more problems with UHF than with VHF. There are pockets throughout the south-eastern coast where residential areas, because of all the hills, are out of sight of the transmitter.

Both WIN and Prime are trying to deal with that by providing better services. Both have tried to strengthen their signals through the establishment of a transmitter at Little Forest Trig which is near Milton. This transmitter means that they can strengthen the signals from Mount Wandera and perhaps Brown Mountain, which is between Bega and Cooma. With that link, Prime and Capital will be better competition down the south-east coast.

Once again, most of the popular programs in the Canberra-Dubbo areas are those on the Nine network, although it must be said that every one of the networks has popular programs. Nine just seems to have a predominance of them.

If we are to maintain choice we must ensure-using our own example-that Prime is economically viable, able to sell advertising and show it has the viewers, and that Capital is economically viable, able to show it has the viewers and can gain advertising-the same as WIN does. This is extremely important because it means that people will continue getting quality television with a maximum of local input, whether sport, news or other programs.

Interestingly, once aggregation occurred Capital stopped screening what it called the Local Member segment when five or six members of parliament were able to have a five-minute session at 11.30 or midnight on a Saturday night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon) for the further elucidation of this matter, but I must say that we are not persuaded to abandon the amendment and we will certainly persist with it. SPEECH.PARA: Subject to section 89b, a licensee may, with the consent in writing of the Tribunal, but without that consent shall not . . . admit another person to participate in any of the benefits of the licence or to exercise any of the powers or authorities granted by the licence.

That was, if you like, step one. Step two was when the Solicitor-General gave his opinion to the effect that the networking agreements that he had seen led him to the conclusion that they did admit another person to participate in any of the benefits of the licence. Indeed, that was, in fact, the reality. This is all set out in the explanatory memorandum which is worth reading.

The second step was that the Solicitor-General concluded that the networking agreements, in fact, did come within that description. Therefore, we are left with the situation that consent had to be given by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). We ask the question: What is wrong with that? What is wrong with requiring the Tribunal to give that consent? I cannot believe that the reason is that the Government wants to remove red tape and bureaucratic control, because we have just passed a Bill which gave another wheelbarrow load of red tape and bureaucratic control to the Tribunal.

I concede that a lot of people find that these things are difficult to get their minds around; but, if one can get the argument up to the stage where the Solicitor-General's opinion is that when one looks at these networking agreements they do seem to give benefits to people and seem to admit people to the benefits of a licence and-although he did not say this-therefore, one can conclude that they should require the consent of the Tribunal, is that such a disastrous situation? The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) has just been telling us-from what I know of it, quite rightly-of some of the attractive results of aggregation. The difficulty is in ensuring equity for both parties to the agreement . . .
It then makes the first point, which is the honourable member's point as follows:

networks should be entitled to reasonable returns for supplying relatively low-cost programming to regional markets . . . whilst there should be scope and incentive for regional operators to sustain and develop local content.

That is also important. We would have thought that, if the Government goes ahead with this proposal, allowing these sorts of agreements without having some supervisory responsibility vested in the Broadcasting Tribunal, at the very least it is taking a risk in so far as the regionals are concerned that they may be dominated to an excessive extent by the networks. I ask the question again: does the Government want to turn the regional stations into complete slaves, chained to the networks? That would seem to be an undesirable thing to do and, if there is that danger, we suggest that the Minister thinks again about it. I think that is all that need be said about that, but we will be proceeding with our amendment on that proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are altruistic.

SPEECH.PARA: One can read the explanatory memorandum. I am not going to read it into Hansard. It is all set out. The Solicitor-General reached the view, which I think is probably right, that these networking arrangements probably breached the 60 per cent rule.

When the Parliamentary Secretary was replying in the second reading debate, he said, in effect, how silly we were for raising this question. I asked, `What is the point of having the 60 per cent audience reach rule if it is going to be negated in effect by legislation as it is being negated here today?'. The audience reach rule was never intended to be one that was limited only to metropolitan areas. It would assist us and ease my passions about this if it could say `the cat sat on the mat' and tell us why it is doing it, preferably in words of one syllable so everyone will understand. As often is the case, these things defy any rational explanation. It seems to be motivated solely by a desire to make the Broadcasting Act even more complicated than it is. We heard the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) saying that he was confused. I can understand why he was confused; but the Government should make the position clear.

The provision that we have here has nonsense in it. We think it is an unwise thing that the Government is doing. It is contrary to advice that the Department apparently gave to the Minister. The Government is negating the law simply to keep the aggregation process going at its present pace.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) has, in rather erudite way, put his position, but I do not think it holds much water. I think that should clarify the position for the honourable member for Menzies.

In relation to the general comments made by the honourable member for Menzies about aggregation, the Government's position is very clear. We do not accept the propositions which have been put by him. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 13, page 7, lines 3 and 4, omit paragraph (a).

This amendment is quite unnecessary because it is a drafting amendment that follows from an amendment which we lost. Therefore, if we now make the drafting technical change, it is going to be a very peculiar Bill. So I should say that, in one sense, I hope the Government is successful in defeating it.

The Government should accept this amendment and the others which have already been rejected by the Government. If one goes back to the history of it-and it is worth while putting this into the Hansard-we are told on page 10 of the explanatory memorandum that on 21 November 1989 the Solicitor-General provided an opinion to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in relation to what are described here as certain draft affiliation agreements. It goes on to say:

These draft agreements provided for the supply of programs between companies representing commercial television networks and regional licensees in approved markets proceeding to direct aggregation of existing regional commercial television service areas.

The explanatory memorandum then goes on to say that the substance of the Solicitor-General's opinion was that the draft affiliation agreement would, if implemented, result in a breach-and I refer only to one of the consequences-of the 60 per cent reach limit. It is true that the Solicitor-General was there highlighting the consequence of having both the audience reach limits, which the Government put into the Act some time ago, and the networking agreements, which came about as a direct result of aggregation. Those networking agreements are, of course, agreements designed to regularise the relationship between the networks and the regional stations. Of course, the two, when one thinks about them, are inconsistent, and it was not surprising that sooner or later a clash would be identified between the two of them, and the Solicitor-General highlighted this clash.

The approach that the Government has taken is to say, `Well, therefore, you must change the law; therefore, you must negate the 60 per cent audience reach rule', and that seems to me to be a very curious way of approaching life. One would have thought that we should have a look at the aggregation system itself. It is just as well that I come from a profession that has regard to the time that it takes to say things rather than simply saying them, and I trust this will be borne in mind in the future. The reality is that, no matter how long it takes to say it and how many times one has to say it, the simple point is that it is unnecessary to follow the course that the Government has adopted.

What the Government should do is approach aggregation itself and say, `Let us have a review of that. Let us look at aggregation. Let us look at where the problems are. Let us look at why it is that some regional television stations do not want to proceed with aggregation'. I cannot believe that the stations are so perverse that they want to put up the shutters against the opportunity of having a wider market and possibly making money out of it. I think they probably do in their heart of hearts want to take a more active and vigorous role in television throughout a bigger area of Australia. But they see obvious problems with it, mainly because of the cost, and they have committed themselves, as I understand it, to vast sums of money to put aggregation into operation. That is the situation they are faced with.

Surely, the logical thing to do would be to have an examination of aggregation itself. This has been the Opposition policy for some time, and the fact that we were not elected at the last election should not be taken as a rejection of this position, because our audience reach was in fact larger than the Government's audience reach, and the proper way to go is to implement that policy. One way of doing it-and it is only one way-is to have an inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal itself, and there is power to have that done. From some of the correspondence that I have seen, it would seem that really the Government has not been following the proper course. It really should have looked seriously at this question of a specific inquiry directed to looking at aggregation itself.

Up until today the Government's argument has been along the lines that there is a licence renewal coming up in the Australian Capital Territory and therefore that is an opportunity to look at aggregation. In fact, more than that is needed; there must be a wider opportunity given for a further examination of aggregation.

I refer again to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). This is the fourth time I have praised him in this debate, and there has to be a limit to it. But the reality is that he rightly drew attention to some of the benefits-and there are benefits-for viewers of having a wider range of choices, a greater choice. We support that on the Opposition side. It is in the interest of viewers to have a wider choice and that is the reason we have been speaking in favour of pay television. We know that for whatever reason these days many people find that they are not being provided with services on television of the type that they want to watch. They having presented to them programs that the television stations want to show-that is true-and in some cases the programs are popular, but there are many sorts of areas that can be presented on television which are not presently provided by the free to air system and which could be provided by pay television. We say, `Choice, yes, you are right about that'.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro is right when he says that aggregation provides a wider choice for viewers, but the point remains that, despite that, there are problems with the implementation of it-with the cost, the timetable, the speed of the introduction, all of which are giving rise to anguish, and that anguish should be addressed properly. It can be addressed by an inquiry by the Broadcasting Tribunal; that is a proper way to go about it. But there is no point in simply coming along, as the Government has-and the present Government is not unique in this, I must admit-and saying, `Well, there are proceedings in the courts that are inconvenient to us. It does not fit in with our structure of the world so we will simply pass a law negating the law and we will say, ``Well, you can go and whistle for your proceedings in the Federal Court''.' That is what the Government is doing here. It is a very bad principle, no matter what government does it. I would think that it probably will not work in this case, but it is a bad principle anyway and not one the Government should embark on and not one that any government should embark upon.

There are other and better ways of solving the problems, as I have said, although we do not deny that there is a problem there that has to be dealt with and addressed properly. One cannot help observing that the Government must be smarting under this because a decision was given in the Federal Court yesterday in these proceedings which the Government lost. It was trying to strike out the statement of claim of the regional stations which are suing the Government. I am sorry to tell the Government that it lost again-I hope with costs.

The Government is trying to frustrate this action and trying to deny people their proper legal rights and I do not believe the Government will succeed. The Government should not even try-that is the point-because it will end up with egg on its face, even more than is usually there. We strongly advise the Government, if it wants advice, to desist from this course and start to act responsibly and properly.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) for his noteworthy contribution to this afternoon's debate. It has been a stimulating afternoon. We have had contributions from all sections of the Parliament. Not the least has been the contribution by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). It has been stimulating by example in one sense because of his erudite knowledge of the law and the way in which, as a learned friend might put it, he is someone who remonstrates with the Government on points of practice as well as points of law. It was good to see that he at least accepted the validity of the Solicitor-General's advice to the Government this afternoon and has not taken a course of action which has hitherto been taken on previous occasions by our opponents when they have condemned actions taken by this Government on the basis of the advice which has been given.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member did seek, however, to try to suggest that the Government was unwise not to take one portion of the advice which was provided to it by the Department of Transport and Communications. I reiterate that the Government may use its judgment as to whether or not it takes all the advice that it receives, and what advice it does take. In the context of this Bill before the House this afternoon, as I have said previously, it chose to take its interpretation of the Solicitor-General's advice. The result of that is the legislation before us this afternoon.

The honourable member for Menzies made some comments about the issue of aggregation and the impact of this legislation on regional stations. If it is true that there is a negative impact upon some regional stations, there is the capacity for them to raise those concerns with the Government. As you well know, Mr Deputy Chairman-I am sure the honourable member for Menzies appreciates this-the Government is conscious of the need for the ongoing review process which is currently under way. This forms part of that review process. The package which has been provided to the House this afternoon has as its objective the provision of more efficient and effective regulation.

I have to go back to the original statement from the honourable member for Menzies, in the context of his speech on this legislation, when he supported the thrust of much of what the Government has been doing. I am a little concerned that there seems to be some ambiguity between the approach taken to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the approach taken to the ABT by the honourable member for Menzies. It is clear that the right honourable member for New England regards the ABT as a bit of an anathema, whereas our friend the honourable member for Menzies, like the Government, believes that the ABT is a significant body which has a valuable contribution to play in broadcasting in Australia. It is within that framework that I understood that the honourable member for Menzies was indicating that he believed that as a result of the amendments proposed by the Opposition the ABT should be given further regulatory powers over broadcasting.

It is not a position which we accept. As I have reiterated previously in this debate, the Government is firmly of the view that the amendments which are proposed to the legislation will provide for addressing problems which have been highlighted by previous practice and will clarify the situation in relation to the advice given to us by the Solicitor-General.

I commend the legislation to the House. I ask the honourable member for Menzies to reconsider his proposals in the context of the discussions that we have had this afternoon, advice he received from the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), and the contributions that have been made by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) and the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe); these should have highlighted for the honourable member for Menzies the need for him to reconsider his proposals, and indeed the Opposition's proposals, in the context of these amendments.

I think he has made a valuable contribution to proceedings this afternoon, and I believe that he has added quite a bit to the discussion.

It is good to see that the debate which we have had this afternoon in the context of these amendments has been taken in the spirit of fair play which we like to see as part of the ongoing practice of the House.
