SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to take the opportunity of making doubly sure that the general thrust of our propositions is firmly on the record. The first point to make is that there are a number of regional television stations which are concerned about what is being done here. I make the additional point that I certainly do not have any brief to stand here and appear for them. Nevertheless, it is significant and important that their point of view should be expressed for two reasons. First of all, they have a major role to play in television presentation in regional and rural areas. Secondly, there has always been assumed to have been an identity of interest almost between the viewers in those areas and the stations themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that when the regional stations express a view, it is not simply a view motivated by their commercial interest, although that is obviously something they take into account, but it is also a view which they present because they identify themselves with people who live in those areas. It is important to understand that when these views are being expressed they are views being expressed with the interests of the viewing public in those areas very much in mind. That must be very clearly understood. Some of those who are concerned about it are the stations known as BCV, GLV, TNT, DDQ, SDQ, NRN, RTN, WIN, RTQ, NBN and Capital. They are concerned, as a number of us are, about what is being done here. In a nutshell, the concern arises, as I have said, because the Government is seeking to insert into the Broadcasting Act a new section 89ea, which I have already referred to, and new subsections 89a (14) and (15).

There is no need to go over these in detail again because I have already done that, but the substance of the amendments that the Government is making to the Broadcasting Act should be understood. One could summarise it by saying that the substance of those amendments is to exempt-that is, to take away from the operation of the relevant ownership and control provisions-control of an otherwise independent licensee arising out of program supply arrangements. As we know, these program supply arrangements are embodied in what are known as networking agreements.

There is concern also about what is in substance-and I do not think the debate we have had has disproved this proposition-the removal of the role and the province of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for its consent to be given to those networking agreements.

Although the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon) has perhaps been engaging-and I do not say this in any critical sense-in a bit of hair splitting, the reality is that section 89a of the Act does in fact require consent. It is not very often that an Act says that consent must be given and then go on to say if it is not given then the Tribunal is not to do something. That is not often found in an Act. Presumably, in so far as this Parliament concentrated on what it was doing when it passed the Broadcasting Act, it really meant it. It was a double assurance that the Tribunal would be required to give consent to those sorts of arrangements. That is being negated here, and that must be clearly understood.

Those stations that I have referred to-and others which have an interest in this matter-recognise that there are defects in the present legislation. Some of them have been highlighted by the opinion of the Solicitor-General. The point must be made-and I say this again without any critical sentiment behind it at all-that the Parliamentary Secretary is quite wrong when he says that there is no need to change the law at all. That is not the case; it is very clear that there have to be some changes here. But the burden of our complaint is that there is no need to make the sorts of changes that are being made here. There is no need to use a sledgehammer because the concentration should be on what the problem is. The problem is the concern that people have about the way in which aggregation is being implemented and the costs that are involved in it, not its end objective. That should be clearly understood. What we say is not that there is no need to change the law, but that it is not being changed in the right way.

This situation has been raised by the Department itself. I come back to the point that this is not simply us just scratching around to find ammunition to hurl over the benches at Government members; it comes from the Department itself where there are some very intelligent, perceptive people at work. What we are saying is that the Government really should be listening to its advice.
It is very important to understand what its advice was. Only as recently as 2 February, the Department informed the Minister in these words:

It can be argued that the dominant supply position of each network, viz-a-viz its affiliates, may threaten those affiliates' ability to retain sufficient revenue to provide programming adapted to local needs. At the same time it is the basis of the Solicitor-General's advice that such arrangements give the networks `legal control' of the affiliates for the purposes of the Broadcasting Act, thus creating various breaches of the Act's ownership and control provisions.

So the advice was given, and the Department recognised when it was giving that advice, that there was a need to improve the regional stations' bargaining power. That is what this is all about-bargaining power. What the Government is really doing by these amendments is committing the regional stations to a slave state. They are being bound to the chariot wheels of the networks and tying them up. They will end up having to show `Spartacus' every night if we go on like this. They really are being put in an inferior position. It would seem to me that it is very undesirable to do that. It is not just the Opposition making this point; the Department has told the Government about it and given advice to the Minister to the effect that something should be done. I will elaborate on the point of what the Department said it should do.
Some steps could be taken to ensure a degree of affiliate bargaining power.

I just ask: has the Government put anything in this Bill which will ensure a degree of affiliate bargaining power for the regionals? (Quorum formed) Before the quorum was called I was drawing the attention of the Committee to the fact-(Extension of time granted). I was making the point that the advice given by the Department to the Minister was that some steps could be taken to ensure a degree of affiliate bargaining power. I ask the rhetorical question: is there anything in this Bill which does ensure a degree of affiliate bargaining power? It is clear that what was in the Act with regard to the extent of any power for affiliates is still there.

It is equally clear that there has been no improvement in the affiliates' bargaining position. There is no increase in that power being written into the Act. So it would seem that the answer to the question that I asked is no. Again I ask: when one sees the advice to the Minister was that some steps could be taken to ensure a degree of local autonomy, is there anything in this Bill which gives a degree of autonomy to the regional channels? No, there is not; there is nothing at all. There is nothing new in this legislation that enhances the autonomy of the regional stations. The advice was that some steps could be taken to ensure programming relevance. Is there anything which is being written into the Bill to enhance program relevance? The answer to that must be no, there is not.

The point remains-it has now been made several times; I am sure that even Government members will understand it-that the advice given by the Department to the Minister has been ignored in this legislation. I gather that the answer to this is, `Well, it is just one piece of advice. There is other advice'. Perhaps we ought to have a look at that, too. That might take up another half hour. We will see whether that advice has been followed. Indeed, there might be contrary advice. In fact, this argument of the Parliamentary Secretary reminds me of Churchill, who said once that he read only every second paragraph of a memorandum from the Foreign Office because every second paragraph started off with `On the other hand'. It seems that the advice given by this Department to the Minister-if we accept what the Parliamentary Secretary has said-may be fashioned on the same principle. Perhaps there is some inconsistent advice. If there is inconsistent advice that says, `No, you really should screw the regional television stations into the dirt', I would like to see that, too. We might have quite a lot to say about that. The point is that the advice goes on to say:
Some powers could be given to the Tribunal-
this is the essential point-
to prevent exploitation of affiliates by the network stations.

Of course that could happen. We make two points about that: one is that, because of the requirement to consent that is in the Act already, that power is there for the Tribunal to prevent exploitation of the regionals. But the Government is diluting it, negating it, and taking it out of the legislation. So the Government is putting regional television stations at risk of being put into a subservient position. That would seem to be a very unhealthy and nonsensical thing to do.

The other point we make about it is that the Government has not put any new power into the Act for the Broadcasting Tribunal to prevent exploitation of affiliates by the network services. It is worth repeating the difficulties expressed in the advice from the Department. Again, I have to praise the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), but it is the last time I will do it-it is the tenth time I have done so-for his contribution, when he said that one of the concerns about aggregation is that the network has to be given some incentive to go into a region and incentives have to be given to the regional stations to spread out and expand their broadcasting into the new areas of aggregation. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro rightly made that point. The Department's advice rightly makes that point. But the Department's advice makes another countervailing point, which states:
Networks should be entitled to reasonable returns for supplying relatively low cost programming to regional markets-
this is the point that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro so adequately made-
whilst there should be scope and incentive for regional operators to sustain and develop local content.

Another paragraph follows on from that one. I will not take up time by reading out additional parts of the advice, but the point must be made that there is nothing at all in this Bill which will give any incentive or scope for regional operators to sustain and develop local content.

Last night we had a lot of heroic speeches, not only from the honourable member for Eden-Monaro-whom I have praised on this matter-but also from the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who made the same point. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), believe it or not, also made a powerful point. They were emphasising what an important part of the broadcasting infrastructure was comprised by regional stations. They were right about that. I ask the question again: If regional broadcasters are so significant, which they clearly are, why is the Government negating them? Why is the Government chopping them off at the feet in this piece of legislation? Why is the Government doing it?

As I have said before in this debate, I wonder why I am trying to persuade the Government to stop committing suicide, which is what the Government is doing. It is alienating a lot of people associated with the regional stations and thereby alienating a lot of their viewers and listeners. The Government is also probably alienating the readers of Hansard at the same time.

I think the basic point is that the Government is right, absolutely right, when it emphasises the importance of regionalism. But here the Government is not only not advancing the interests of regional stations and their viewers but is also going contrary to their interests. The Government has already been warned that what it is doing here is running the risk of putting regional stations in a subservient position, turning them into slaves, chaining them up to the chariot wheels of the networks. That is the great danger of what the Government is doing. We believe very strongly that that is not a course that the Government should follow. It is not in the interests of broadcasting as a whole. It is not in the interests of regional broadcasting. It is certainly not in the interests of the stations themselves, and it is not in the interests of viewers, because the Government is running a risk of destroying the local content element of regional broadcasting.

The example that I gave before was probably too extreme but it seemed to get people's attention, which was that there could be a networking agreement that said, `There will not be any local news at all. We will provide the news for you'. It is hard to imagine the networks doing that, but the reality is that they will be driven by commercial interests and who can blame them for that? In one case, they are acting in the interests of a receiver of the company and, in the other, the interests of their shareholders. Of course, they will be motivated by commercial interest and fair commercial interest will always be paramount over and above the commercial interests of a regional station.

Quite clearly, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said, one should always back self-interest because one knows it is trying. No doubt the networks will be motivated, among other lofty motives, by that principle. Obviously they will not be writing into the network agreements clause after clause to benefit the regional stations: they will be writing clauses in to benefit themselves, and who can blame them for doing that? There must be an umpire, someone to stand, in effect, between these quite disparate commercial interests of the networks on the one hand and the regionals on the other.

The Government is denying that: it is preventing that from happening. It is not just bad legislation; it is not in the interests of the stations, their viewers and, as I have said one or twice before, it is not in the Government's own interests. I do not know why it is doing this. We seek to persuade the Government from that course and urge it to think again about what it is doing in this case.

What all this comes down to is a spotlight being put on this problem in the law by the Solicitor-General who, on this occasion, was right. He is not always right, but who is? But on this occasion I think the Solicitor-General was right. I agree with him. If the Government went along to the Solicitor-General today and said, `Thanks for your advice. What we are going to do to implement the advice is to pass a law that stops people from going to the Federal Court to promote their legitimate interests in a case which they have already started', the Solicitor-General would say, `I didn't give you advice to that effect. I didn't tell you to do that. That's not the advice I gave you'. So the Government cannot rely as far as it has on the Solicitor-General's opinion.

We urge the Government to think again about this because what it is doing is not in the interests of any of the parties involved. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). I must say that from my office and the chamber the language that he used was most persuasive to me and I have been forced in fact to come from my office to the chamber to see this performance of persuasion at first hand and to rehearse in my mind the arguments that are being used by the honourable member. I thank him for the opportunity of seeing his persuasive powers both in my room and in the chamber. I am completely persuaded and I cannot understand why members of the Government and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon) are not also persuaded.

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe it is the repetition of the salient points that has persuaded me. Maybe it is the expanded arguments that have been injected on each occasion that have persuaded me. However, the principle of what the honourable member for Menzies has been saying is really at the nub of the Bills we are considering today.

The honourable member has used language such as `chaining the regional stations to the wheels of the chariots of the network'. I think that is a proper description of what has occurred. He has spoken of putting them into slavery. What he is saying in wonderfully descriptive language is, `Put your shackles on my wrists and take me away into slavery because I am no longer able to control the programs that are so earnestly wanted by the people that I serve as a regional television station'.

The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) is in the chamber. I know that his network system in the north of Queensland is critical to the people in his State and to that great area of tourism and commerce that he serves. The honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) is also in the chamber. I know that he would love to have a regional station unshackled, not chained to the chariot wheel, serving the western part of Sydney.

But no, the Government has chosen not to take that path. It has chosen to say that through the process of having the programs nominated by the networks these regional stations will not be their own people: they will not be able to serve the people of Fowler, northern Queensland or even Parramatta. I see that the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) is in the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill makes provision to enable the Remuneration Tribunal to make determinations in respect of those matters covered by the provisions of the Remuneration and Allowances Bill 1990 passed by the Parliament today, except for the basic salary of members of parliament which is linked to movements in the Senior Executive Service band 1.

In particular, in the context of amendments made to that Bill in the Senate relating to the levels of remuneration of Whips and other office holders from all parties the Remuneration Tribunal should be asked to review the relativities of a number of offices. All parties supported that approach. The Bill provides that such determinations can be made, operative from 2 June 1990. In addition, amendments made by this Bill will ensure that nothing in the Bill overrides the operation of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990 which gained the royal assent last week.

Further amendments are made to preserve the operation and effect of previous determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal which relate to parliamentary secretaries, travelling allowance for parliamentarians and other office holders and other matters which are not replaced by the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it clear on behalf of the Opposition at the outset that the Opposition understands why the Remuneration and Allowances (Amendment) Bill 1990 is necessary, but let me say to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) that the speech that he has just delivered has characterised the Government's handling of this issue over the last 48 hours. What the Minister did not tell the Parliament is that this Bill is necessary because the Government has advice from Parliamentary Counsel that the effect of the legislation passed through this Parliament in the last 24 hours has been to repeal the provisions of the Parliamentary Allowances Act which, of course, was made necessary by the ultra vires conduct of the third Hawke Government in helping itself to the public exchequer in relation to postage stamps.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it clear that, although the Opposition has supported the direction of this Bill, we would be failing in our obligation to the Parliament-and I suggest the Government is failing in this itself-in not having something to say about the extraordinary incompetence which has characterised the Government's handling of this issue. After all, it claims to be the greatest Ministry since World War II. It claims to have on the front bench a luxurious array of talent. It claims to have available to it the best and brightest minds in the nation to give it advice. It claims to attract people like a magnet in terms of its administration and its discharge of its ministerial responsibilities.

True it is that the Minister at the table will say to us, `You had the Bill, why didn't you spot the problem?'. There is a bit of a difference when the Opposition has only 10 minutes, and does not have the resources of government at its disposal. It might be a valid argument if the normal rules obtained but, of course, the normal rules did not obtain. He might also say that it has long been a convention in this Parliament that when matters relating to salaries and allowances are dealt with it is all done in a great hurry.

It used to be done by the Leader of the Opposition asking the Prime Minister a question about how members' emoluments had lagged behind. That process was always proceeded with because people assumed that there was competence on the part of the government and that it could get it right. But it has taken this Government not one, not two, not three but four bites of the cherry-and even now I cannot say, on behalf of the Opposition, that I am satisfied that this is okay. I do not have the resources to say that. I said to my colleagues this afternoon in a shadow ministry meeting that I cannot guarantee them, in the short time that is available, that there is not some other legal or administrative flaw in this particular piece of legislation. Yet we are told that this is the greatest Ministry since World War II.

I know there are a lot of people who want to go home, but occasionally reverence and concern for this place transcends travel convenience. It has been a characteristic of the fourth Hawke Government, in the two weeks and two days that this Parliament has met, to treat this institution with contempt. It started with the address of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the National Press Club on the consumption tax. It has been continued with the attitude taken by the Government towards the televising of Parliament. After this `Fawlty Towers' performance, one really knows why the Government does not want to televise the House of Representatives. How would it look-the fourth Hawke Government, in all its resplendent, brilliant glory, looking monumentally incompetent.

The truth is that this is what happens when a government is in bondage to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The reality of this whole remuneration saga is that, if the Government were not in bondage to the ACTU and did not have to get the permission of Martin Ferguson and Bill Kelty to deal with parliamentary and other matters, it would not be in this particular predicament.

Whilst it is not the view of the Opposition that this Bill should be denied a second reading because it purports, as it were, to affirm what people thought they were doing last night, I move the following amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time:

At end of motion, add: That whilst not denying this Bill a second reading, this House is of the opinion that the Government's handling of this and related legislation displays extraordinary administrative and ministerial incompetence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion. The farce surrounding the Remuneration and Allowances (Amendment) Bill was seen last night when the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) was found to be totally out of control of the Parliament and had no comprehension as to what this legislative action was to be, let alone what his motions to be moved were. I observed him last night as he mouthed the words of the Clerk at every turn, and saw that he was totally bereft as to what was transpiring at that point of time in this House. That, in a way, crystallised the Government's attitude to the legislation itself.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been-I will use a delicate term-a monumental stuff-up from the beginning. It goes back to stamps, when the Government was caught with its fingers in the till and my predecessor, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), as the shadow Attorney-General, called the Government's bluff when it tried to jack up the stamp allowance from $9,000 to $30,000. He took the Government to the High Court of Australia. The High Court found five-love-five-nil-in favour of the honourable member for Menzies. It brought the Government to the point where, despite that decision of the High Court, its then Minister told its parliamentarians and others in the Senate to keep spending-to spend, spend, spend. It mattered not what the High Court had done. The Government brought in legislation to try to validate the whole thing; we moved sensible amendments; the Senate supported us; the legislation went through and became the Parliamentary Entitlements Act.

One of the elements of this remunerations Bill, of course, has been to try to sneak through the back door again a discretion to vest in the Minister the right to overrule the Remuneration Tribunal and, as a consequence, the Government is invalidating-with the legislation that has gone through Parliament-that Parliamentary Entitlements Act.

It takes a touch of exquisite genius to stuff it up like this but, boy, the Government did it. In the words of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), this claims to be the greatest Ministry since Federation and it cannot even get its stamps right, let alone the entitlements that it perceives to be necessary and the way in which they ought to be paid, despite what the Tribunal has said.

The passage of the Remuneration and Allowances Bill has, allegedly, inadvertently repealed the substance of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act in that the former purports to reinstate the discretion of the Minister for Administrative Services to allocate benefits, which discretion had been limited by the Parliamentary Entitlements Act. Fair dinkum, I have never seen a performance like it and I do not think too many of those who have served in this Parliament for a long time on the Government's side of the House have seen it either. It is unique.

Not only has the Government sought to defy the law in the past, not only has it been aberrant morally in terms of the expenditure in the election campaign; but when the Government seeks to try to validate a proposition, it also invalidates the legislation that has hitherto been passed by the Parliament. As I say, a touch of exquisite genius. There is much that I could say on this matter-for instance, I could reiterate the provisions of the Bill-but I will not do so. The honourable member for Bennelong has pointed out just what the Government has reduced this Parliament to. No wonder it is held in disfavour and discredit. I will not detain honourable members any longer. I strongly support the amendment of the honourable member for Bennelong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an old saying, `Oh what a tangled web we weave, when first we practise to deceive!'
—That's a bit rough.

—No it is not, because the problem that the Government is faced with now-the shambles that has been visited upon it-comes from its attempt to deceive the Australian people from the very beginning. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) has made it perfectly plain. He was absolutely right when he said that this whole saga began when the Government was not prepared to accept the lawful decision of the Remuneration Tribunal on postage allowances. It was the proper role of the Remuneration Tribunal to examine that matter. It was within the law. But the Government decided, for the basest of political reasons, to seize that decision from the Remuneration Tribunal, and said, `No, there is an election coming up and we want more in postage allowances so we will, illegally, take it away from the Remuneration Tribunal and do it ourselves', and the Government increased the $9,000 postage allowance to $30,000.

SPEECH.PARA: That was an illegal act. The Government was told that it was an illegal act. A number of honourable members on this side of the Parliament told the Government that it was an illegal act, and, instead of doing the reasonable and sensible thing, instead of looking at it rationally and calming the situation down, the Government's response was simply to ridicule us. The Government said that it was nonsense and the then Minister advised Government members to go ahead and spend, spend, spend-spend the $30,000. The matter went to the High Court of Australia and the Government got its comeuppance. It was put firmly back in its place and it was told that it had acted illegally.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you haven't got the costs yet.

—As the honourable member for Kooyong reminds us, not only did the Government lose five-love, not only did the court deliver one judgment, but, also, an order for costs was made against the Government which have not been paid. Not only was there one very glaring illegality where the Government was utterly exposed and defeated, but it has also compounded the whole thing because it now says to those honourable members who have overspent illegally, `Well, we will twist and contort the discretion that the Minister for Finance has so that those illegally paid moneys will not be paid back'. That is the course that the Government has now embarked upon-to twist and contort the discretion of the Minister for Finance-and that is equally reprehensible.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the course that the Government started on. That is the road it decided to go down and from that original deception has come this utter and complete shambles. The Government needed legislation to undo what it had done illegally in the first place-it tried to do that illegally and retrospectively-and this is what it is faced with today. The whole thing is a disgrace and the Government should be utterly ashamed of itself. I utterly support, without any qualification, the propositions that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has put.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Commonwealth laws would apply to attempts to (a) bribe Members of the Federal Parliament or (b) offer other considerations in exchange for actions by Members or Ministers of the Federal Parliament of benefit to the person providing the considerations.
(2) Do minimum and maximum penalties apply to such actions; if so what are the penalties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 73a of the Crimes Act 1914 makes it an offence:
for a Member of Parliament to receive, ask for, or offer a bribe to exercise his/her authority in a particular way, and
for another person to offer a bribe to a Member of Parliament for such a purpose.
Section 88 of that Act may also be relevant in some cases. It creates an offence of buying or selling offices. It relates to the obtaining of employment in the Australian Public Service.

(2) The maximum penalty prescribed by both sections of the Crimes Act 1914 referred to above is imprisonment for 2 years. Pursuant to sub-section 4b (2) of the Crimes Act 1914 a pecuniary penalty of up to $12,000 may be imposed in addition to, or in substitution for, the term of imprisonment.

These are indictable offences and therefore subject to the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 which would empower a court to order the confiscation of any benefit received. The provisions of the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act 1989 also apply to Members of Parliament who are charged with an offence involving an abuse of office, or committed for a purpose involving corruption or to pervert the course of justice.

This empowers a court to order that the offender is not entitled to any superannuation benefits, paid or payable by the Commonwealth, other than his/her employee contributions and interest accrued on those contributions.
